story:
97 Compton Avenue was burnt beyond repair and now the Jennings family needs our help to rebuild and move on. 

 

Imagine losing everything you've ever owned. That's what we're trying to replace. While that is a nearly impossible task, together we'll get pretty freakin' close. 

 Why set a goal of $4,200 when the losses are far and above that number?

  1. Processing fees are smaller if we achieve our fundraising goal
  2. In honor of our recently passed father, who only deals with numbers that are multiples of 420 (air guitar!).

 

Any amount helps and all of it goes towards helping Steph, Ed, and Lisa get back on their feet. 

 

Thank you so much for your help! 

 

In the news:

  1. http://holmdel-hazlet.patch.com/articles/fire-in-west-keansburg-home-draws-large-response-from-bayshore-fire-departments-video
  2. http://www.app.com/article/20130305/NJNEWS/303050145/Hazlet-fire-ruled-accidental-after-residents-safely-escape

story:
Kyangwali Revolution

 

Refugees at the Kyangwali Refugee Settlement Target Root Causes of Violence and Aggression in Conflict Areas of the Eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo

I. Kyangwali Revolution Goals:

  • Refugees at Kyangwali identify and alleviate root causes of conflict in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo and thus hostile areas experience lowered levels of violence and aggression;
  • Exploit the power of technology, The Internet and open social media for the benefit of the Revolution and ensure an extensive and transparent platform for the world to participate as an active decision-maker. Kyangwali is everyone’s revolution.

The Kyangwali Refugee Settlement in Western Uganda is located near to the eastern border of the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

Refugees and their stories are clear evidence of the violence and aggression in conflict areas of the eastern DR Congo.

Village members will identify and target root causes and thus experience decreased levels of violence and aggression in their home country.

The use of social media and the Internet as a catalyst for empowerment, action and change will play an integral part in the interactive adaptability and exposure of this research's findings for the world.

 

Contents (Full Research Plan)

I. Kyangwali Revolution Goals

II. Kyangwali

III. Evidence of Violence and Aggression in Conflict Areas of the Eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo

IV. Root Causes of Violence and Aggression in Conflict Areas of the Eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo

V. Refugees at the Kyangwali Refugee Settlement Target Root Causes of Violence and Aggression in Conflict Areas of the Eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo

VI. Decreased Violence and Aggression

VII. Technology, The Internet and Social Media as a Catalyst for Empowerment, Action and Change

VIII. Supporting Organizations

IX. Kyangwali Revolution Team

X. Professional and Educational Background - Jason Ricciardi - Principal Investigator

XI. Budget and Support

XII. Other Support

XIII. Protection of Subjects  

 

I. Kyangwali Revolution Goals:

 

  • Refugees at Kyangwali identify and alleviate root causes of conflict in the Eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo and thus hostile areas experience decreased levels of violence and aggression;
  • Exploit the power of technology, The Internet and open social media for the benefit of the Revolution and ensure an extensive and transparent platform for the world to participate as an active decision-maker. Kyangwali is everyone’s revolution.

 

     The following research plan is geared towards exposing and actively involving its Internet audience to various links with updates from primary resources on the ground about Kyangwali, the conflict in the DR Congo and the root causes of the violence and aggression there. For educational and practical purposes, this will include accounts and connections to all sides of the story and will expose all perspectives including those of rebel forces. Please refer to this website for news, information and interactive media direct from the Kyangwali Revolution and feel free to circulate the webpage and start spreading the word! https://www.facebook.com/pages/Kyangwali-Revolution/135263449996137

 

II. Kyangwali           

 

     Located in Western Uganda and near to the border of the Eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo, the Kyangwali Refugee Settlement hosts approximately 25,000 predominantly Congolese and Sudanese Refugees including a small percentage of Rwandese, Burundians, Somalis, and Ethiopians. Due to tribal conflicts, corruption and violation of human rights caused by irresponsible leadership and an underpowered community, they were forced to leave their home countries. As a result, they were strained into the Kyangwali Refugee Village: A community characterized by extreme poverty, disease, depression and most importantly, poor education.                      

Joseph Munyambanza - Founder - CIYOTA 'International Youth Organization to Transform Africa' - Kyangwali Settlement Webpage: http://coburwas.org/communities/  

 

III. Evidence of Violence and Aggression in Conflict Areas of the Eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo

 

     Reports and accounts from village refugees themselves, other organizations already compiling statistics and oppositional force representatives about the root causes of violence and aggression in their home countries will be posted to the website. Also, please refer to the videos and pictures there for a wide variety of perspectives on recent history in the DR Congo and in addition the comment sections where interactive users are provided a platform to start voicing their opinions on integral and important matters and decisions. The online stage will be as communicable as possible for everyone and also full of eyewitness accounts of conflict happening in Central Africa.

      Here are notes from praised professionals on violence and aggression in the DR Congo. Please feel free to follow the links to learn more: 

From 1996 until the present, The Eastern DR Congo has experienced a death toll of an estimated 6 million lives in the struggle for control over the nation's abundant natural resources, including but not limited to: Gold, Diamonds, Copper, Cobalt, Coltan, Zinc, Niobium, Titanium, Manganese, Uranium, Iron and Tin.

- 'Crisis in the Congo: Uncovering the Truth': http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vLV9szEu9Ag

Hundreds of thousands of women systematically raped as a strategy of war.

- Maurice Carney - Co-Founder and Executive Director - Friends of the Congo: http://www.friendsofthecongo.org/  

Rape happened to be one of the weapons that worked the most because as soon as you destabilize a community, you rape the entire village in front of the children, in

front of the husband, in front of the neighbors. That community is broken completely.

- Nita Evele - Congo Global Action: http://cgacoalition.org/

It has nothing to do with Ethnicity. They killed Congolese like flies.

- Kambale Musavuli - Congolese Human Rights Activist: http://kambale.com/ 

     As of November 2012, more than 2.4 million Congolese were internally displaced and more than 460,000 had become refugees in neighboring countries. Myriad armed groups threaten civilians in North Kivu, South Kivu and Orientale provinces, uprooting families from their homes and taking away their livelihoods when not killing or raping them outright.

- Refugees International: http://www.refugeesinternational.org/where-we-work/africa/dr-congo 

     Every month, 45,000 more Congolese—half of them children—die from hunger, preventable disease, and other consequences of violence and displacement. Over one million people have fled their homes within Congo as a result of the ongoing conflict. Eastern Congo right now is perhaps the worst place in the world to be a woman. Used as a weapon of war, rape in Congo exists on a scale seen nowhere else in the world. Often successful in its intent to destroy and exterminate, rape as

a weapon of war is causing the near total destruction of women, their families, and their communities.

- Enough Project - 'Roots of the Crisis - Congo': http://www.enoughproject.org/conflict_areas/eastern_congo/roots-crisis

 

IV. Root Causes of Violence and Aggression in Conflict Areas of the Eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo

 

     An extensive and comprehensive analysis of the root causes of violence and aggression in conflict areas of the eastern DRC will be performed with the refugees by way of formal and informal interviews. Along with already existing information and statistics, Revolution participants should be able to formulate concise ideas about the root causes and what they are definitively if they already have not. This information will be added and posted to the project webpage and online users will be able to view and comment on it directly with the refugees at Kyangwali.

     The following have been expressed as major concerns already from CIYOTA leaders: irresponsible leadership and an underpowered community; lack of education or skills to allow village members to solve their own problems, both in the refugee camp and back in their home countries and; lack of skilled, principled and visionary leaders who stand against many odds in Kyangwali and beyond.

     The following is an identification of root causes from The Enough Project:

     The current crisis in eastern Congo illustrates the historical patterns at the root of this conflict: as long as the Congolese government cannot control its territory, provide basic services or effectively protect its population, and as long as armed groups are able to prosper from illicit trade in natural resources and complex regional alliances, Eastern Congo will remain a battlefield and innocent civilians will pay a tragically high cost.

- Enough Project - 'Roots of the Crisis - Congo' - http://www.enoughproject.org/files/pdf/crisis_roots_congo.pdf

 

     This portion of the research plan requires a vast compilation of reliable sources from the ground. This project is going to make that possible.

 

V. Refugees at the Kyangwali Refugee Settlement Target Root Causes of Violence and Aggression in Conflict Areas of the Eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo

 

     The Kyangwali Revolution primarily seeks to empower refugees at the settlement to target the root causes of violence and aggression in their home countries.

     Via extensive and proven leadership training with Educate!, an organization that develops young leaders and entrepreneurs in Uganda, by providing long-term mentorship and two-years of world-class leadership and entrepreneurship training to help high school students start enterprises that solve poverty, disease, violence and environmental degradation, the Kyangwali Refugees will grow empowered and prepared to accomplish Revolution Goals for themselves. Educate! has also partnered with The Government of Uganda and the UN International Labor Organization (ILO) to incorporate its leadership and entrepreneurship curriculum into the national education system. The curriculum now reaches 25,000 students annually. More information on the Educate! leadership curriculum can be found here: http://www.experienceeducate.org/.

 

VI. Decreased Violence and Aggression

 

Kyangwali Revolution Goal 1: Refugees at Kyangwali identify and alleviate root causes of conflict in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo and thus hostile areas experience decreased levels of violence and aggression.

     This is for very many reasons a long-term and sustained goal, but a lot of the foundation can be set within the first year.

     Monitoring and evaluation will be based on but not limited to the development of social media websites with compelling evidence like eyewitness ideas and accounts from Kyangwali Revolutionaries and oppositional parties, videos, pictures and credible statistics concerning identification of and solutions to root causes of conflict from partnered NPOs such as the UNHCR, Government of Uganda and Educate! - An organization that already practices reliable monitoring and evaluation systems with equally reliable indicators. Those documents are available upon request and their model will be used as a foundation for this Revolution.

     Lastly, tracking progress will be as interactive as possible for the world, thus ensuring complete transparency and maximum exposure. This will also remedy requirements surrounding supporter relations by allowing them to view progress in real time and by offering continuous opportunities to actively participate as revolutionaries too. 

 

VII.  Social Media and the Internet as a Catalyst for Empowerment, Action and Change

 

Kyangwali Revolution Goal 2: Exploit the power of technology, The Internet and open social media for the benefit of the Revolution and ensure an extensive and transparent platform for the world to participate as an active decision-maker. Kyangwali is everyone’s revolution.

     The interactive piece of this movement has already begun here: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Kyangwali-Revolution/135263449996137 Visit the Kyangwali Revolution Facebook page and start influencing real sustainable change in the Democratic Republic of the Congo now!

 

VIII. Supporting Organizations

 

  • CIYOTA - 'International Youth Organization to Transform Africa' -http://coburwas.org/
  • Educate! - 'Developing Young Leaders and Entrepreneurs in Africa' -http://www.experienceeducate.org/
  • UNHCR - 'The UN Refugee Agency' - http://www.unhcr.org/cgi-bin/texis/vtx/home
  • The Government of Uganda - http://www.statehouse.go.ug/state-house-administration/departments/poverty-alleviation 
  • UN International Labor Organization - 'Promoting Jobs, Protecting People' -http://www.ilo.org/global/lang--en/index.htm 

 

IX. Kyangwali Revolution Team

 

CIYOTA Staff: http://coburwas.org/about-coburwas/ 

On-site International Volunteer Group:

  • Director of African Operations/Women's Programs - Catherine Fowler
  • Director of African Operations/Program Manager - Yazan Fattaleh
  • Director of African Operations/Community Builder - Jason Ricciardi (Principal Investigator)

And of course...

The Kyangwali Youth, Women, Village, Leaders, Volunteers and You - Revolution Supporters.

 

X. Professional and Educational Background - Jason Ricciardi - Principal Investigator

 

Professional:

  • Education, Empowerment, International Community Development and Linguistics Specialist;
  • Operational in English, Spanish, French, Italian, Korean, Quichua and aspiring proficiency in languages native to Uganda, DR Congo, South Sudan, Rwanda, Burundi, Somalia and Ethiopia;
  • High level of management experience, interest, creation, and implementation of community-based empowerment projects, impact analyses and social networking as a catalyst for empowerment, action and change.

 

Educational:

Master of Arts in Government and Politics - St. John's University - Rome, Italy

  • International Relations concentration; Public Personnel Administration minor; International Law and Diplomacy certified.

Bachelor of Arts in Criminal Justice - Stonehill College - Boston, United States of America

  • Psychology minor.  

Note: CV included with application.

 

XI. Budget and Support

 

     As a representative of CIYOTA, and with your help and support I will be traveling to the Kyangwali Refugee Settlement to help address the very concerns that have been expressed by community members: irresponsible leadership and an underpowered community; lack of education or skills to allow village members to solve their own problems, both in the refugee camp and back in their home countries and; lack of skilled, principled and visionary leaders who stand against many odds in Kyangwali and beyond.

     This is a call for support that will allow me to travel and live in Kyangwali for an expected period of at least one year, which as a result will help to accomplish established Kyangwali Revolution Goals. Costs have been budgeted out to cover expenses like: Transportation; Consular; Health; Living; Communications; and Miscellaneous Costs (see detailed budget at the end of this application). Finances will be tracked, accounted for and available for viewing online. There are also possibilities to funnel funds into programming, impact and change, and it will be interesting to see what You, Revolution Supporters would like to see happen with project resources. Voice your opinions here: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Kyangwali-Revolution/135263449996137

     This revolution can be as interactive as you'd like it to be. We want you to be directly creating change too.

     CIYOTA is a United States registered 501(c)3 charity with tax id number 27-309274.

 

XII. Other Support

 

     Based on the social nature of the assignment, facilities and the community itself at Kyangwali will suffice more than enough to conduct research with members of the village. Living facilities are secured as described in the budget. Facilities during travel are available, but have to be evaluated more so upon arrival.

     The Kyangwali Revolution campaign is currently active on indiegogo.com, an online funding platform, and can be viewed here: http://igg.me/at/Inspire-Social-Revolutions-In-Africa/x/2898921 This is also another center for project information and updates from the field. Until now, the project has received $105 in monetary support.

 

XIII. Protection of Subjects

 

     The majority of this research is social in nature and demands the efforts of the people themselves to identify and attack root causes, and create real sustainable change. Considering the CIYOTA and Educate! programs are based on that and their projects follow similar goals too, there already exists an acceptance. They are the ones who inspired me to create this proposal. The following is a diagram and explanation of the CIYOTA model: 

     In everything we do, a sense of responsibility for community development is fostered, and CIYOTA leaders strive to empower every individual they touch to be a problem-solving, visionary leader for change. Members at local, national and international levels share the principle of developing a united, self-sustained community starting from zero to what great leaders and entrepreneurs have never imagined.

     The Tri-fold approach coupled with emphasis on strong sense of ownership for the community by the community and passion for Pan-Africa. We understand that to create great leadership and entrepreneurs without character can be detrimental, but also teaching character without leadership and entrepreneurship would leave the current and next generation of leaders unprepared to face the responsibilities and opportunities to make Africa a better place.

- CIYOTA - ‘Our Model’ - http://coburwas.org/offices/

Finances will be tracked, accounted for and available for viewing online. There are also possibilities to funnel funds into programming, impact and change, and it will be interesting to see what You, Revolution Supporters would like to see happen with project resources. Voice your opinions here: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Kyangwali-Revolution/135263449996137
     This revolution can be as interactive as you'd like it to be. We want you to be directly creating change too.
     CIYOTA is a United States registered 501(c)3 charity with tax id number 27-309274.
 
XII. Other Support
 
     Based on the social nature of the assignment, facilities and the community itself at Kyangwali will suffice more than enough to conduct research with members of the village. Living facilities are secured as described in the budget. Facilities during travel are available, but have to be evaluated more so upon arrival.
     The Kyangwali Revolution campaign is currently active on indiegogo.com, an online funding platform, and can be viewed here: http://igg.me/at/Inspire-Social-Revolutions-In-Africa/x/2898921 This is also another center for project information and updates from the field. Until now, the project has received $105 in monetary support.
 
XIII. Protection of Subjects
 
     The majority of this research is social in nature and demands the efforts of the people themselves to identify and attack root causes, and create real sustainable change. Considering the CIYOTA and Educate! programs are based on that and their projects follow similar goals too, there already exists an acceptance. They are the ones who inspired me to create this proposal. The following is a diagram and explanation of the CIYOTA model: 
     In everything we do, a sense of responsibility for community development is fostered, and CIYOTA leaders strive to empower every individual they touch to be a problem-solving, visionary leader for change. Members at local, national and international levels share the principle of developing a united, self-sustained community starting from zero to what great leaders and entrepreneurs have never imagined.
     The Tri-fold approach coupled with emphasis on strong sense of ownership for the community by the community and passion for Pan-Africa. We understand that to create great leadership and entrepreneurs without character can be detrimental, but also teaching character without leadership and entrepreneurship would leave the current and next generation of leaders unprepared to face the responsibilities and opportunities to make Africa a better place.
- CIYOTA - ‘Our Model’ - http://coburwas.org/offices/

story:
About AUW

The Asian University for Women is an international liberal arts university in Chittagong, Bangladesh that seeks to empower women to become leaders in their own communities and across the world. AUW has students from 16 countries across Asia and the Middle East, including Afghanistan, Myanmar, Palestine, and Syria. Relying almost entirely on donations, AUW provides generous scholarships to 99 percent of its students. As many women in Asia still struggle to get the education they deserve, AUW is doing invaluable work for gender equality.


The Impact

With your donation, our students will be able to conduct research projects, attend conferences, prepare for graduate school, have access to books and school supplies, join the basketball team, and become service-oriented leaders.  Your donation will go straight to funding one of our phenomenal students. We strive to inspire socially conscious, ethical leaders, and your generosity helps us do that. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t contribute, you can still help:

  • Like us on Facebook: Asian University for Women
  • Follow us on Twitter: Asian University for Women
  • Share our campaign: Email your friends/family about what we are trying to do and share our video on Facebook/Twitter
  • Visit our website and sign up for our email updates!

story:
Poznaniak=a person from Poznan

I am Amanda Dibben, a recent graduate from Hollins University, an alternative processes photographer, and a hopeful Poznaniak!

This summer I was accepted for the English language Master's of Arts program at the University of Arts In Poznan (Uniwersytet Artystyczny w Poznaniu) where I hope to expand my love of art and photography, buiding on a unique process of printing photographs on copper and bringing this into printmaking and mixedmedia works. 

I was able to attend Hollins University, a prestigious all-women's college, through a full-tuition scholarship based on my academic and leadership abilities. At the time, I never thought I'd get into graduate school, much less one located in Poland. 

Even though the costs of attendance in Poland are much less than in the US, I am not able to come up with all the funds myself. The only way students can get a student loan for an international school is if they study law, medicine, or business. But because I'm studying creative arts, I get no federal financial aid and no banks will give me a student loan. This is the reason I've come here to ask you for help.

 

What I Need & What You Get

For two years of study I need a total of $35,000. I have about a third of it, and am looking at other resources for the rest, but am hoping to raise $7,500 here. 

Everything I raise here, whether it's $200 or the full $7,500, will go towards my living expenses: transport costs, my first months of rent and deposit, initial study costs of books and supplies, and general groceries, even if it's Cup Noodles all week long!

If you donate $20 I'll send you a super awesome postcard from Poznan about how amazing you are for helping and how much you should come to the great city of Poznan!

For $100, I'll send you the postcard and a photograph. It'll be an 8x10 signed and numbered photograph of a great landmark I find in Poznan. It will be a digital print with archival ink, so it'll last you a lifetime.

For $300, I'll send you the postcard, the landmark photograph from Poznan, and an additional series of four 8 x 10 archivally printed photographs from Warsaw, Krakow, and Poznan.

Then there's the big one. If you donate $1,000 I will send you one of my copper pieces. The image and the piece will be the only one like it in the world, not even I can replicate them. They are signed and framed. There is a further description below and you can see images of my pieces at vault13photography.weebly.com.

More Information

My final project for my Studio Art Bachelor's was a series of portraits printed on copper. Since I started experimenting and researching my process, I have not been able to find any other artist that does the same thing and creates photographs like mine. The reason it is so unique is that the image is developed directly onto the copper, there is no digital printing or transferring of the image. This was a very time intensive project as I had to discover everything for myself, although I had a ton of help with ideas and presentation from my advisors and professors. 

In May, I presented my final project of 13 images and graduated cum laude with a Margaret Markley Smith Award for Studio Art from Hollins University.

I feel that it is important to share my art and continue it in the world. I want other young artists to be able to see what I do and let it inspire themselves to create something new. I think all too often young artists have a belief that it's all been done before, but it hasn't. There are always new ways to see and create art. This is the idea I want to bring to Poland, to be able to see art with a new group people and experience what they feel and think when I present works to them.

Also, I think the hardest goal of mine is to learn Polish while I'm there. Languages have always been hard for me!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this with anyone you know! I want other photographers to see this just as much as your accountant, everyone's an artist with what they do!

story:
We are the freshman class at Mount Madonna School.  We are raising funds to go on a a trip to Catalina Island for our Marine Biology class.  After we go we will make a video to educate our community about the importance of ocean conservation.  The name for our project is Yeyeco Ica Atl.  It means Flow With Water in the language of the first humans to live on Catalina. 

We would like to go on this learning journey, and we would like to create a documentary about what we learn to share with other students and the greater community.  In addition, we would like to support ocean conservation in our community by doing three beach cleanups. 

The project will be a great opportunity for our class to become more knowledgeable and gain a greater apreciation for Marine Biology from hands-on learning.  We will gain experience in organization, fundraising, cooperation, and travelling as a group.  This will prepare us for future learning journeys.  Travelling as a school group will allow us to experience our ecosystem in a deeper way than we would be able to on our own. 

We have prepared for our studies by assisting field researchers with conservation work at Elkhorn Slough.  See the article in our local paper about the work we have already done!

story:
UPDATE: 100% of the funds go to SIS; the university in general will not see any of it.  You do NOT need to be affiliated with SIS to donate!  The wider our support, the more powerful our message!  Thanks everybody!

Short Summary

Academia is ALL politics, and any loss of power, symbolic or otherwise, is HUGE.

With the University of the Pacific's recent decision to have the College of the Pacific (COP) absorb the School of International Studies (SIS), alumni, students, and friends of SIS have spoken out in defense of the unique program.  The decision was announced August 23rd and the plan is to be in place by October 1st without any input from current, past, and future students. That means that all students who are currently enrolled and may have chosen Pacific for its autonomous SIS (not to mention those on their way) and have been paying tuition for years will be out of luck. 

Most importantly, faculty evaluation/promotion and tenure, academic standards, curriculum, etc., will be merged with the College. The College Dean and College committees will be the relevant authorities for those processes.

While we should continue to write letters, post comments, and let the school know that we do not support their decision, the fact remains that money speaks volumes more than words to a private university.  

Whether or not the university will reconsider its decision remains to be seen, but we can send this very clear message: SIS alums and friend care about the school and are willing to donate... but we can happily take our dollars elsewhere.  Should the university continue with this plan we will no longer be alumni of a school, and our alumni dollars will have nowhere to go.  Donations will cease.

What We Need & What You Get

As such, we propose that we raise $5,000 to donate with the express purpose that it be given to the School of International Studies' endowment.  Whether or not the university will reconsider their action, this money will go a long way in helping the school maintain the programs that will be at risk to be cut.  For this year, SIS has been assured that their budget will remain intact.  Again and again the provost has said "for now" and "this year," but they have been very strategic in refusing to make any long-term promises.  The signs are clear that the SIS budget may be at risk.

When we donate the money, we are allowed to specifically state exactly what its use will be.  We can decide to use it for SIS student scholarships, faculty/student research grants, etc.  What we decide to use it for will depend on how much money we raise, but the money will go directly to SIS.

As we continue in our campaign for the preservation of our home, we will draft a donation letter, on which every donor's name will be included.  The more you donate, the higher your name will be in separate tiers.  We sadly cannot do physical perks, but we are open to suggestions should anybody have any.

Help us, as Provost Pallavicini claims the purpose of this reorganization is, "extend and enhance international education at University of the Pacific

If we do not reach our entire goal, we will receive a percentage of the funds and still be able to donate some money to the school.  $5,000 is a big enough number that sends an enormous message and only requires 50 people to donate $100.
Of course, we are hoping to break that number at hit at least $5,000.  If you cannot give $100, give what you can!  Even $10 is appreciated!

Why $5,000?  It is both a realistic and significant goal that is attainable with your and your families' help.  It was recently suggested to me that SIS alums and their supporters can only raise "tens of thousands of cents."  At most, that would be $999.99.  Let's prove him wrong.

 

The Success of SIS and the Failure of Pacific

SIS has turned out award winning students year after year.  Each year the school is trumpeted by the university as an amazing program that produces these prestigious award winners, but every admissions initiative and marketing plan has left SIS in the dust.  Being the only School of International Studies, SIS could have positioned itself as the alternative to the East Coast DC pull.  With the proper guidance, support, and funding, SIS could have been huge, as evidence below.  Students, however, knew the university saw SIS as a low priority after the Arabic class fiasco that hurt SIS's position in academia for years to follow.

Pickering Award Scholars (20 awarded nationally):

  • Khatijah Corey 

Fulbright Scholars over only the past two years:

  • Joe Styers
  • David Allen
  • Nicholas Freeman
  • Karelli Cabral

Boren Scholarship winners:

  • Shannon Chapman
  • Krystal Leonard
  • Devon Blount
  • Kelly Walker
  • Trevor Rosenbery
  • Anzeliza Lapid (alternate)

Phi Beta Kappa members:

 

  • 2012
    • Karelli D. Cabral
    • Margaret C. Fielder
    • Marissa K. Ito
    • Kaitlynn Leier
  • 2011
    • David P. Allen
    • Jessica L. Garland
    • Kristal L. Leonard
    • Joseph P. Styers
    • Erik J. West
  • 2010
    • Anna Bernard-Hoverstad
    • Jessica Chittaphong
    • Alexander T. Francis
    • William W. Castillo Guardado
    • Ashley L. Horne
    • Taylor J. Skinner
    • Julie A. Tam
    • Samantha C. Wildman
  • 2009
    • Catherine A. Cloud
    • R. Joel Strauss
    • Nicholas P. Tyson
  • 2008
    • Leslie A. Abitz
    • Melissa E. Brennan
    • Hillary M. King
    • Bonnie A. Lucero
    • Andrew V. Summers
  • 2007 (The first year of PBK at Pacific)
    • Nicole M. Dalton
    • Megan J. Thomas
    • Cheri F. Kramer

Phi Kappa Phi Members:

  • 2012
    • Karelli D. Cabral
    • Maya Campbell Unsoeld
    • Margaret C. Fielder
    • Marissa K. Ito
  • 2011
    • David P. Allen
    • Caroline M. Fantozzi
    • Jessica L. Garland
    • Kristal L. Leonard
    • Joseph P. Styers
  • 2010
    • Anna Bernard-Hoverstad
    • Nathan Freeland
    • William W. Castillo Guardado
    • Julie A. Tam
  • 2009
    • Catherine A. Cloud
    • R. Joel Strauss
  • 2008
    • Hillary M. King
  • 2007
    • Nicole M. Dalton
    • Megan J. Thomas
  • 2006
    • Amy E. Baird
    • Sarah E. Bulley
    • Paula Burt
    • Trisha L. Bury
    • Jarek N. Stanley
  • 2005
    • Elizabeth A. Shrafman
    • Kiyomi C. Urbas
  • 2004
    • Kali E. Drake
    • Paige L. Elisha
    • Franziska Frey
    • Becky L. Jeffers
    • Jennifer A. Laedlein
    • Kelly M. Lentz
    • Jordan D. Svien
  • 2003
    • Melanie A. Badinski
    • Ann R. Barnett
    • Ananda P. Case
    • Karisa T. Cloward
    • Oona E. Mallett
    • Jeanine V. Turell

With all these award winners, you would think that SIS would be marketing gold for the university.  Having traveled to and spoken at admission events in Oregon, Washington, Arizona, Orange County, and San Diego over three years, I (Taylor S.) can definitively say that SIS is not something the University valued or tried to market to students.  Enrollment may be down in the program, but the University has not tried to change that.  SIS can be the best program in the country, but since it is not housed in a top university, the program will not market itself.  Instead, recruiting has focused heavily on Pharmacy and Engineering (which are both amazing programs), and SIS has been left in the dust.  The fact that Pharmacy and Engineering students stay longer and thus pay more tuition probably factors in this decision.

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out on this campaign!  Send it to your family and non-SIS students and alum on campus.  $5,000 is just the goal, but if we can blast past that, then we can do a really good thing for our school!  SHARE THIS PAGE!

Who We Are

Taylor Skinner - SIS Class of 2010

Campaign Coordinator

Taylor graduated from both SIS and COP in 2010 and was one of many SIS Phi Beta Kappa inductees.  Having worked with both schools, he understands that different majors and programs require different environments to thrive and be effective tools of education.  As a student of SIS he benefited from a $3,000 grant that took only 12 minutes for the dean to approve, a process that takes weeks in larger schools.  He studied abroad in Japan, and after receiving his masters in Political Science at UCSD went to work for the Giving Department at TOMS Shoes, using the development knowledge and world history he learned in classes like Contemporary World Issues, Development Economics, and International Relations. 

James Pollard - SIS Class of 2008

Alumni Coordinator

James graduated from SIS in 2008 in the IR&GS program with work also in Anthropology and Economics.

Sam Wildman - SIS Class of 2010

Finance Coordinator

Sam graduated from SIS in 2010 with a double major in Political Science at COP and IR&GS at SIS and was one of many SIS Phi Beta Kappa inductees.  Having spent time as Treasurer in ASUOP, Sam understands how budgeting at the University works and how important it is for a school to have true autonomy and the power of a Dean.  She studied abroad in Korea, and after graduating and traveling in Ireland, Sam was admitted to Arizona State University's Sandra Day O'Connor school of law, which is a top tier school currently ranked 26th in the nation.

Get the word out on this campaign!  Send it to your family and non-SIS students and alum on campus.  $5,000 is just the goal, but if we can blast past that, then we can do a really good thing for our school!  SHARE THIS PAGE!
Who We Are
Taylor Skinner - SIS Class of 2010
Campaign Coordinator

Taylor graduated from both SIS and COP in 2010 and was one of many SIS Phi Beta Kappa inductees.  Having worked with both schools, he understands that different majors and programs require different environments to thrive and be effective tools of education.  As a student of SIS he benefited from a $3,000 grant that took only 12 minutes for the dean to approve, a process that takes weeks in larger schools.  He studied abroad in Japan, and after receiving his masters in Political Science at UCSD went to work for the Giving Department at TOMS Shoes, using the development knowledge and world history he learned in classes like Contemporary World Issues, Development Economics, and International Relations. 
James Pollard - SIS Class of 2008
Alumni Coordinator

James graduated from SIS in 2008 in the IR&GS program with work also in Anthropology and Economics.
Sam Wildman - SIS Class of 2010
Finance Coordinator

Sam graduated from SIS in 2010 with a double major in Political Science at COP and IR&GS at SIS and was one of many SIS Phi Beta Kappa inductees.  Having spent time as Treasurer in ASUOP, Sam understands how budgeting at the University works and how important it is for a school to have true autonomy and the power of a Dean.  She studied abroad in Korea, and after graduating and traveling in Ireland, Sam was admitted to Arizona State University's Sandra Day O'Connor school of law, which is a top tier school currently ranked 26th in the nation.

story:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION 

In 2013, Meow Wolf and Albuquerque Museum will initiate a groundbreaking arts education project called Project Dreamscape.  From January until May, 12 high school participants will work with experienced Meow Wolf instructors to design an immersive, multi-media installation that will open to the public at The Albuquerque Museum on Friday, May 10th.

  Through the process of Project Dreamscape, these high school artists will learn how empty space can be transformed into vivid experience through the amalgamation of artistic mediums and the collaborative process.

  At this point, Project Dreamscape can afford two Meow Wolf instructors per week, and $4000 worth of materials to construct the installation. The students’ ideas so far have been nothing short of fantastic, and to fully bring these ideas to life we would need to increase our current budget.  

  We are seeking $15,000 of funding to support 12 Meow Wolf instructors per week and supply Project Dreamscape with a total of $8,000 worth of material.  This will allow for one-to-one ratio of Meow Wolf artist to student per week, and will give us the proper amount of funding for the materials that will make this project truly amazing.

  Project Dreamscape will open to the public on May 10th, 2013 at The Albuquerque Museum of Art and History.

story:
WE ARE EXCITED TO ANNOUNCE THAT WE WERE JUST INVITED TO EXTEND OUR PROGRAMMING THROUGH THE FALL, WITH A FULL RUN IN NOVEMBER!

We have just met our initial goal for summer programming! Now, with 1 DAY left...lets double this! 

 

Truthworker Theatre Company, founded and directed by Samara Gaev, is launching this summer! We are a social justice based, hip-hop theatre company for high school and college aged youth in Brooklyn, NY. 

For over a decade, I have been working as a youth theatre director and educator for grassroots arts organizations and cultural institutions throughout New York City. The relationships that I have cultivated with young artists and activists over the years have been truly transformative. The most impactful exchange as a teaching artist is that moment when my students express their hunger to continue developing their craft under my direction.

Truthworker Theatre Company is intent upon providing free programming for young visionaries and performers to receive rigorous professional training this summer. Summer intensives in the arts are often costly and, consequently, are limited to only those who can afford them. I am determined to continue the momentum with this powerful community of young people and offer them the space, the training and the creative direction, as well as opportunities to:

  • Collectively devise

  • Work with guest artists

  • See live performance in the city

  • Perform original work in a professional theatre. 

 

 

 

In addition to offering a free, safe space for creation, collaboration, and learning, I hope to provide a stipend to each young company member who fully commits to and completes the project. This stipend is my affirmation of valuing the arts as an avenue for sustainable career paths and life choices. I want these young artists to take themselves seriously, know their value, and believe that the arts can truly be a sustainable and legitimate passion. In the face of an economy that continues to cut budgets for the arts in our public school system, I hope to affirm that if my students approach their craft with discipline and commitment, following the path of the arts can indeed be a tool towards supporting themselves.  

This summer, Truthworker Theatre Company will be working in partnership with JACK -a new performance space located in Clinton Hill. All workshops, rehearsals, and performances will be running out of JACK. Stay tuned for performance details! Projected date: Aug. 11th, 4pm (www.jackny.org)

Please consider supporting the hard work that Truthworker Theatre Company is deeply committed to. While our full budget for TTC far exceeds what we are asking for here, the amount we are hoping to raise through this campaign will allow us to operate for the four weeks. As we launch this summer, we hope that you can help us meet or exceed our financial goal of $8,000 so that we can bring our programatic visions to fruition.

WAYS YOU CAN HELP

  • Please give what you can

  • Post this campaign via email, facebook, twitter

  • Tell people about Truthworker Theatre Co.

  • Refer an aspiring artist for Truthworker Theatre Company's summer intensive

 

Thank you so much for being a part of this important initiative!

 

                                  -----UPDATE-----

 

 

Truthworker Theatre Company launched programming on July 6th! 

Please help us reach our fundraising goal!

Within the first week, we grew each day both in numbers and as artists and quickly delved into the devising process. By the close of our first week, our 15 member company was already begging for more time to work together as they passionately began to develop an original work called:

BAR CODE: A Performative Analysis of the School to Prison Pipeline. 

The devotion of the company members has been remarkable. Each day, we have had 100% attendance with everyone showing up early and staying late--squeezing every second out of our time together. The young members of TTC have been stepping up to the plate in taking on all of the responsibilities of bringing their creative visions to fruition. From gathering statistics and compiling research, to staying up late in the studio mixing and mastering an audio score for their work, each facet of this process has been youth led and driven.

 

 

So many moments have occurred in our society during this short time that we have used as fodder, inspiration, education, and a call for further analysis, but non as poignant as the Zimmerman trial. The verdict landed pretty heavily in the hearts of our young people- stirring up a world of emotions, questions, fears, and demands. It is a great honor and a great challenge to uphold a safe space for learning, reflecting, mobilizing, and truth telling. While I feel so sad that this is the legacy our young one's have inherited, I am all the more charged with encouraging my students to use their art to broadcast the stories that go missing so that we can begin the process of collectively healing and transforming our future.

 

 

Truthworker Theatre Company has just completed three vibrant and productive weeks of rigorous programming! We are two weeks away from our final performance on August 11th!

BAR CODE: A Performative Analysis of the School to Prison Pipeline

We are so grateful to the guests who have blessed us with their stories and expertise as we strive to create work that reflects the narratives that so often go untold in our communities. As part of programming, I have been committed to bringing bi-weekely speakers and guest artists such as Malik Yoba, Climbing Poetree, and Nsangou Njikam to work with our youth. This last week, we were honored to welcome a powerful guest speaker, Zaki, who came to share with us about his experience with the Prison Industrial Complex as a formerly incarcerated youth who spent 16 years inside from the tender age of 16. He is now a powerful educator, activist, and mentor in the NYC schools, detention centers, and beyond. It was insightful, inspiring, informative and, most importantly, eye opening. 

       

                         Dancer in Photo: Oddisey Miller, Truthworker Theatre Company

I am blown away by the continued generosity of my community far and wide! There are few things more invigorating than receiving the heartfelt support and faith that each of you has placed in my work and vision. At this point, we have 2 days left to surpass our Indiegogo Campaign goal. This is a modest goal for the amount of work and resources that a program like this calls for. Already, the company has requested props, costumes, and set designs that would bring their vision to fruition, not to mention food, water, transportation, and all of the unexpected day-to-day expenses and production costs that have arisen. Having said that, we hope to exceed $8,000 in the next 2 days so that not only can their final performance be as powerful as they envision it, but so that we can continue to do this work beyond the summer!

          

August 11th, 2013 @4pm

 Jack (505 1/2 Waverly Ave, Brooklyn NY)

 

                                                               In Gratitude,

 Jack (505 1/2 Waverly Ave, Brooklyn NY)
 
                                                               In Gratitude,

story:
"If we can raise $3,600 from this campaign, we will have raised enough to provide 10 students with scholarships! Help us reach that goal so we can move on to our next one: Raising money for University Scholarships! Thanks for your generosity and for truly making a difference in the lives of these incredible young people!" --Michael, Amy, Josh, Jessica, & Daniel, and the rest of the VyM Team.   

Short Summary

This summer, we worked with a remarkable group of 10 students in Rabinal, Guatemala who have a profound vision for the future. In the words of 16 year old Lilian Bolvito:

"What I hope to achieve is to become a Doctor so that I can help others in my community to have good health. Today, I am working as hard as I can so that I can reach my goal, and also so that I can be example that anything in life is possible with effort and perseverence." 

Lilian has the self-confidance, dedication, and perseverence to reach her dream. What her family doesn't have is the money to pay for her schooling. Will you help her?

By making a contribution of $5, $45, $90, $180 or more, you can enable Lilian and 9 of her equally remarkable classmates to stay in school and reach their dreams. 

What We Need & What You Get

A full year's scholarship in Rabinal costs $360 per year. Our goal with this campaign is to raise $1,800: This will put us half way toward the full $3,600 we need to provide scholarships for all 10 of our students. 

  • Your $360 contribution will provide a student a full scholarship for a year! To express our gratitude for this contribution, we will send you a beautiful handmade Guatemalan Weaving. 
  • Your $180 contribution will provide a 1/2 scholarship for one of our students. As a thank you gift, we will send you a handbag, locally made in Guatemala. 
  • Your contribution of $90 will provide 1/4 of a scholarship for one of our students. As a thank you gift, we will send you a beautiful hand-made Guatemalan wood carving. 

Contributions of any amount are hugely appreciated, and will make it possible for these students to get the education they deserve, the education that means more to them and their families than anything else in the world. 

The Impact

The impact of your donation does not end with the students you support. Your contribution is a vote of confidance in these young people's potential to transform their communities and change the world. 

Read these stories of how our program has helped students realize their potential:

  • Macario Vasquez Reyes' family is so poor, they could not afford to keep all their kids in school at the same time. Macario would work one year to save up enough money to go to school, then study the next.  Thanks to the scholarship, his is now just a month away from graduating as a certified elementary school teacher. Through Voces y Manos, Macario has developed into an outstanding community leader, and bilingual educator.
  • In middle school, Dinora considered herself just an average student. She did not know whether she would be able to continue studying at the high school level. With the Voces y Manos scholarship, Dinora has discovered her latent potential in mathamatics: she now leads her class. In addition, she worked with a group of her peers to start 13 community gardens. For Dinora, community leadership and education go hand in hand. 

The students in the VyM program show us time and again their potential for changing their communities and the world. What they need is an opportunity. Please help provide them with that opportunity by making a contribution today!

story:
About me:

http://youtu.be/dK9GBM4RZUY

Hello. My name is Melissa. I am currently an Interior Designer in New York City. That's what I went to school for, but I've always had a passion for people, especially kids. I like figuring them out, seeing how they act and finding out what is important to them.

I am also a crossfitter. If you're not familiar with CrossFit, you should check it out: http://community.crossfit.com/what-is-crossfit. Through CrossFit I learned of an amazing partnership between CrossFit Kids and this other initiative that was also teaching kids life skills; Infant Swim Resource (ISR). I checked out the ISR website (http://www.infantswim.com/) read up on their program and watched all the inspiring (not to mention adorable) videos of infants, yes infants, learning how to save themselves from drowning. A light bulb turned on. This was something I wanted to be a part of. 

What I Need & What You Get

In order to become a certified ISR instructor I need to complete some pretty intense training, which costs money. $12,000 to be exact. I have received a scholarship through CrossFit Kids for half of the tuition, but I need to raise the remaining $6,000 on my own. This is where you come in.

The program in total consists of 8 weeks of classes, 5 days a week, for 4 hours a day. It is both in water, with actual babies, and in the classroom lead by a Master ISR Instructor. The class is offered in Florida, which means temporarily relocating my life for the duration of the program. All the money raised will go toward paying the tuition for this amazing opportunity and I wouldn't be able to do it without you!

The Perks

Click the link for a personal explanation of each perk:
 
$10 = http://youtu.be/ROtZQyi4hSE
 
$35 = http://youtu.be/s721dw9Yp9g
 
$100 = http://youtu.be/Oza1tyx78KY
 
$250 = http://youtu.be/qkw1lBYrgQg
 
$500 = http://youtu.be/McWYU3a7U58

See the side bar of this page for additional details and to claim your perk!

Even if I don't reach my entire goal, I will use the funds that I do raise to supplement the cost of tuition. Every little bit helps and I truly appreciate anything you are able to donate.

The Impact

I encourage you to check out the ISR website to learn just how valuable this program is and how it is striving to save lives: http://www.infantswim.com/

Other Ways You Can Help

For those of you that just can’t contribute, that doesn't mean you can’t help:

Get the word out and make some noise about my campaign! I truly believe the best advertisement is word of mouth. If you want to help save babies, but just don't have the funds to support my goal right now, you can still help by telling everyone you know! Use the Indiegogo share tools to facebook/email/twitter blast my link: indiegogo.com/savethebabies! You spreading the word is enormously helpful, even if I don't meet my goal, the more people that know about this amazing program and opportunity, the more babies are saved by learning invaluable life/safety skills.

That’s all there is to it.

story:
Hi! My name is Maree Guenole

Thanks for checking out my project.  

I have an offer to attend Sotheby's Institute of Art London. I will study for a Master of Arts specialising in East Asian Art.

What's special about this? This is an object based programme allowing me the opportunity to handle and view the art I am studying first hand.

Why am I doing this? This is an unique opportunity for me to study with some of the world's most knowledgeable and experienced teachers in their field. There is nothing similar offered in my home country New Zealand.

How will I benefit? I am a passionate art aficianado, I paint, write and collect. I will become immersed in Asian Art esthetiques to fully appreciate the continent's art history and the market for the objects created there. I look forward to a career that will incorporate my passion for writing, hunting for treasure and allow me time in between to pursue my creativity.

What will my outcomes be? I will complete a Master's programme with one of the world's best institutes in its field and thereafter have the ability to identify and share with others what makes Asian Art so beautiful and the qualities that make it desirable. And I will pay 5% forward to another project in the future.

I appreciate this chance to share with you my passion and excitement about my dream.

18, 335 km represents the distance from Auckland to Bloomsbury to undertake my MA. Could you please help me get there?

The objective of my project is to undertake professional development to grow my knowledge of East Asian Art forms and appreciation for these.

This is 14 months of study with a thesis requirement. This opportunity will give me the knowledge to understand and identify objects and art created in East Asia both historical and contemporary first hand because I will be able to handle the objects rather than look at them in a book or in slides. This is what sets the programme apart.

I am really excited to be going. I have been working on this project for 5 years and I am thrilled to be accepted to study under the direction of Dr Anne Farrer.

Apart from visiting art fairs, auction houses, galleries, and museums my class will also travel to China.

In the event this project does not proceed I will notify all backers and be moving to London later in the year to begin work on how I may approach the same programme of study from there rather than NZ with a view to applying for the next intake.

Please give me a boost to get there!
story_txt:
Hi! My name is Maree Guenole 
Thanks for checking out my project.  
I have an offer to attend Sotheby's Institute of Art London. I will study for a Master of Arts specialising in East Asian Art.
What's special about this? This is an object based programme allowing me the opportunity to handle and view the art I am studying first hand.
Why am I doing this? This is an unique opportunity for me to study with some of the world's most knowledgeable and experienced teachers in their field. There is nothing similar offered in my home country New Zealand.
How will I benefit? I am a passionate art aficianado, I paint, write and collect. I will become immersed in Asian Art esthetiques to fully appreciate the continent's art history and the market for the objects created there. I look forward to a career that will incorporate my passion for writing, hunting for treasure and allow me time in between to pursue my creativity.
What will my outcomes be? I will complete a Master's programme with one of the world's best institutes in its field and thereafter have the ability to identify and share with others what makes Asian Art so beautiful and the qualities that make it desirable. And I will pay 5% forward to another project in the future.

I appreciate this chance to share with you my passion and excitement about my dream.
18, 335 km represents the distance from Auckland to Bloomsbury to undertake my MA. Could you please help me get there?
The objective of my project is to undertake professional development to grow my knowledge of East Asian Art forms and appreciation for these.
This is 14 months of study with a thesis requirement. This opportunity will give me the knowledge to understand and identify objects and art created in East Asia both historical and contemporary first hand because I will be able to handle the objects rather than look at them in a book or in slides. This is what sets the programme apart.
I am really excited to be going. I have been working on this project for 5 years and I am thrilled to be accepted to study under the direction of Dr Anne Farrer.
Apart from visiting art fairs, auction houses, galleries, and museums my class will also travel to China.
In the event this project does not proceed I will notify all backers and be moving to London later in the year to begin work on how I may approach the same programme of study from there rather than NZ with a view to applying for the next intake.
Please give me a boost to get there!

story:
Short Summary

Sol Studios Fairfax is a local Yoga / Movement / Music Studio that offers a variety of classes and styles practiced in both heated and non-heated environments. Our passion is enriching the lives of our friends and the community here in Fairfax -- not only with yoga; but also through monthly music and performance events, as well as holistic health presentations. Our classes cater to everyone -- from the beginner that's new to yoga to the more experienced yogis/yoginis.

Ever since we officially opened our doors in June 2013, we've dreamed of creating a studio that is not only exceptional; but truly unique: A studio that is designed with you in mind -- classes tailored to your needs, a flexible schedule and a continuous flow of education and cultural enrichment. Yoga is evolving and we are on the cutting edge of this evolution. Through science and research, we are fusing east and west modalities for the modern day Yogini.

We want to make Sol Studios Fairfax not only the best; but the most beautiful studio in Marin...all this while keeping our prices the lowest in the county.

But in order to achieve our goals, we need to make some significant investments: in the studio and through teacher education. This includes the following:  

  • Purchasing yoga accessories: new mats, more props; 
  • Adding more classes & instructors; scholarship fund for children/elders,teacher education, free community classes and health talks.
  • Expanding the facilities to include a shower, chairs, improved acoustic treatment & sound system, and a small retail / snack shop.. 
Since this is your community, we hope that you will help us make Sol Studios Fairfax the best it can be. 

What We Need & What You Get

The estimated total cost to make these improvements is $21,000. We've already invested $8,000+ in improvements since we purchased the previous yoga business on site; the additional $21,000 will be used as follows ( a percentage of funds received is taken by indiegogo )

 Teacher education & scholarship fund 4,000 Mats - $500, Computer with barcode scanner - $1600, Back Jack Chairs -$900 , Folding Chairs $230, PA system $2000, Acoustic Panels $2900, Signage $500, Rugs $300, Props $2000, Outdoor tables $600, Repairs ( shower, electrical, heating ) $ 650, Painting $250, Desk $250, Curtains $ 300 , PR $500, Lighting $250, Retail setup,snacks refreshments, bottles,clothes,music $3000

The Impact

When you give something, you get something in return! Here's what you'll get for your contribution: ( see side bar )

Not only will you get an even more fantastic studio to practice your yoga , but also :

Level 1 Donation- SolStudios T-shirt

Level 2- Sol Studio Fairfax t-shirt and yogamat

Level 3 - One on one session with instuctor of your choice and a mat

Level 4- One month class package and a mat

Level 5- One on one session with instuctor of your choice, a mat, 1 month class package and 10 free downloads of music from Sol Studios OM Station music library.

Level 6 -  The Prime Mover status ! and all of the above !

 

What happens if we don't reach our goal? We'll use the funds we receive to do as much as possible to make Sol Studios Fairfax the best it can be. Any contribution will be helpful.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? Know others that might be interested? Help spread the word!

Forward this on to your friends, via email or on Facebook!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
We would like to thank all of you for your interest in our Group & Campaign!

 

As many of you know, we research Paranormal occurances mainly on the west coast and have done so for many years. Much like our more popular TV teams, we strive for answers, however we do not have the tv network funding to back us. As the technology gets improved and more expensive, it becomes harder for us to maintain an up-to-date equipment list without some kind of funding to do so. We have relied solely on our own income outside of our group, but as our followers and friends on social media become so massive, we feel we need to step up our game in order to show how much we care about those that follow and friend us on the social media side of our group!

 

We are starting this campaign in order to get the funding required for us to get an internet based start in online sales in order to fund our project without any further donations from our fantastic followers and friends. These items will include Shirts and similar items that may be of interest to you as a funding partner.

Many of our Contributors will be investing into some of our merchandise that they will receive as one of the perks for that contribution. We have a new Logo which is Biker Based, but elegant and will be printed on our shirts and other merchandise. Our founder is an avid rider of Harley's, Loves Rock Music and likes to go to strange places, thus the reason we like to go to Haunted Places.
 
Even if our goal isn't reached, the funding will go to exactly what we need to get started on our sales, equipment will come later if need be... Never the less, we will continue to try to bring our Personalities, Differences, Love and Passion for the Paranormal to you, our friends and family!
 
By contributing to our campaign, we can continue to bring you our crazy, unorthodox, but serious Ghost/Paranormal Adventures as seen on our youtube channel. As you can see, we have Season 1 Episode 2 (Lassen Community Hospital) linked to this campaign, but our pilot episode  compared to the newest episode shows how much we have dedicated to this exploration of the unknown.
 
Although this campaign is asking for a cash donation, there are other ways you can help us. Spread the word by using the Share Buttons labeled on this page to share to your social media account. You can also donate equipment to us as well, like Rem-Pods, Flir Thermal Camera, by e-mailing us: info@capsparanormal.org
 
Help us spread the word of the unknown, lets not feel like we are abnormal because we feel others think were crazy that we believe in the afterlife

story:
PLeDGE Health

In many countries around the world there is no 911; there are no emergency medicine doctors. PLeDGE Health is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit striving to change that by engaging our volunteer health care professionals in global medicine development projects. We believe this model will build the skills of our volunteers while supporting the development of emergency health care delivery in countries that really need it.

Through our development model we:

  • Tackle projects where trainees are presented with global health challenges.
  • Transform our volunteers into better leaders, providers and people.
  • Design programs to support our global partners in achieving their goals. 

We are currently working with physicians, nurses and prehospital providers in Nepal and Zimbabwe to develop emergency medicine as a specialty.

PLeDGE Your Support

As a newly formed nonprofit we are fundraising for our initial capital. To date, we have formed and operated purely on volunteer efforts and $2000 in donations from our founding officers. As we are preparing for our first two inaugural training and education symposiums we need additional funding. Our goal of $20,000, while not covering the total operating expenses of the first year and running the two conferences, will assist us in leveraging funding. Money raised will help us fund:

  • 1st annual National Prehospital Medicine and Disaster Preparedness conference in Kathmandu, Nepal.
  • 1st annual Zimbabwe Emergency Medical Society Training and Education Symposium.
  • Emergency Medicine Specialty Training Development in Zimbabwe.

Every Dollar Counts. Every Donor Counts.

Even the smallest contribution brings us closer to improving emergency medicine globally. Every dollar is tax deductible. Your donation will be used to fund: 

  • Direct costs of conferences in Nepal & Zimbabwe
  • Development of open source educational materials
  • Outreach and support of specialty development

Share our Story With Your Friends

You are important to us! Please:

  • Like us at www.facebook.com/PLeDGEHealth
  • Follow us at www.twitter.com/PLeDGEHealth
  • Tweet about us
  • Email your friends our link www.pledgehealth.org
  • Consider volunteering your skills

Impact on a Shoestring Budget

We are very excited by our programs and have received interest from the World Health Organization, United States Agency for International Development, and individuals within both ministries of health. These programs are well timed to capitalize on growing interest in disaster preparedness and to spark further commitment in the development of emergency medicine training. 

We are raising the profile of emergency medical care in both Nepal and Zimbabwe. We have sponsored the formation of the Nepal Emergency Medicine Organization. In Zimbabwe we have united several interested parties into reforming the now defunct Zimbabwe Emergency Medicine Society. In addition, we have identified physicians actively working on specialty training development and are providing them support in curriculum development and identifying consultant physicians to assist with their program development. 

We appreciate your interest, and pledge to keep you updated on our projects. Depending on your level of contribution, we have some truly exciting perks to celebrate your support of our projects. All of the artwork listed has been purchased directly from artisans in Zimbabwe and represents one of the many industries working towards economic recovery in the country.

story:
My name is Etay Koren. I'm 18 years old and was born in Israel. I'm a ballet dancer and I started when I was 5. This summer I went to Kirov Academy of Ballet of Washington D.C which is one of the best academys in the world and I got a full scholarship for the summer program which is 6 weeks only. After being there for a while they offered me a full artistic scholarship for the year round program. The second I have heard this I knew I wanna be there for the year round program!!! 

Beyond the tuition I need to pay for housing food and registration fees. I can not start the year until these funds are not paid. So I could start the application process I need to get the basic amount which is $ 3,500.

The reason that my family can not help me is because my parents divorced and my mother had cancer so she barely works. Beyond that I have no relatives who can help me.

I'm very serious about my ballet life since I was a litlle boy. Kirov academy of Ballet is a great place where I really can develop into a professional dancer.

please help make my dream come true

story:
Why Gardens?
Because gardens produce healthier food. Only 2% of American children eat enough fruits and vegetables, and 1 in 3 American children born after 2000 is at risk for Type II diabetes. A garden is an introduction to the real, healthy food students and families need access to.

Because gardens can help fix America's nature deficit. With more than 80% of Americans living in cities and suburbs, we need to work harder than ever to teach the values of natural processes.

Because gardens are a living laboratory for education. Not just healthy food—a lesson on what producing healthy food requires. Not just exposure to nature—a way for children to literally harvest the fruits of their labor.

A True Seed Investment 
For as little as $10, you can help a community reap all the benefits a garden has to offer. In just 39 days, we plan to raise $2500 per garden; to feed,  teach, and inspire people in each of these 100 communities. Here are a few things our garden plans to do with your donations:

A school garden at Harmony Science Academy Elementary would serve many educational purposes. Students will become responsible caretakers while learning about the agricultural processes and interactions of living and non-living things that help sustain life. It will also serve to aid in teaching students about healthy lifestyles and what they eat. Students can also learn about composting, life cycles and eating in season. Not only will it provide us with more hands-on learning, it will also build a sense of pride and community at our school through creating and taking care of the garden as a team.The garden will be located behind the school and adjacent to the playground. As you can see from the pictures, it is a very unattractive space that we would like to convert into a pleasant and positive space for our students.

CHECK OUT THE GALLERY FOR IMAGES & VIDEOS

Look Good, Do Good
With every contribution to our garden, donors will receive organic, ethical perks from PACT. Our socks, undies, and t-shirts are produced to high standards of sustainability, with the comfiest organic materials we can find. You'll be giving out of the goodness of your heart, and in return you'll get PACT goodies. It's a win-win situation.

story:
Our Story

Mac Ha, located 7 km from Sapa town in Northern Vietnam, is the most impoverished area of the Sapa region. There are over 1,000 Black H'mong ethnic minority people living in and around Ma Cha village. Sapa Rooms supports the 120 children in the school from kindergarten to 5th grade. Our long term focus is to continue to support the Ma Cha school so these children are able to have a more comfortable environment in which to learn, grow and develop.  As we believe education is the key to breaking the cycle of poverty.


Before Sapa Rooms support, most of these children had no shoes, many had no pants and they certainly had next to no school resources. Going to school in Winter for these children was and still is extremely difficult. Close your eyes and imagine for a moment what it must be like for these children to firstly walk up to 6km bare foot over rice fields to school each morning when the temperature in winter is often minus 5 degrees celsius. the children sit in cold cement class rooms with no heating while the wind whistles through the broken windows and doors.

Christmas 2009, Sapa Rooms donated USD2,500 of duck down jackets at the request of the teachers, there were 120 jackets altogether donated, one for each child. These jackets have been fantastic in keeping the children warm.  The time has come to purchase another set of jackets to keep the children warm this winter.  

US$ 25 is all it costs to purchase one warm jacket.  If you donate US$ 50 your generosity will allow us to keep two children toasty warm this winter.  Warm your heart while you warm a child with your generosity.


What We Need & What You Get

Already we have ordered and are making the jackets in Saigon, south Vietnam.  We choose Saigon as the quality of the jackets are the best while the cost is cheaper.  The jackets will be completed in 15 days.  In time for TET lunar new Year when all the children are at home huddled around the fire trying to remain warm.

Our goal is to give each student at Ma Cha School a duck down warm jacket by 30 January... Please help us.
