story:
Thank You!!!

This is a huge thank you to all who participated in and contributed to the very first Philadelphia Youth Project", it was very successful. The generous contributions and assistance from family, friends and my new found associates was also a huge factor to the Philadelphia Youth Project. This was the beginning of many many more events to come. My goal is to be a positive influence to the youth and through the Philadelphia Youth Project, I will be able to fulfill my goal.

 

What is The Philadelphia Youth Project (PYP)?

The goal of the Philadelphia Youth Project (PYP) is to engage, encourage and educate the youth in Philadelphia through community events, ‘life-building’ workshops and educational events.

 

Why I am starting the Philadelphia Youth Project?

My name is Christopher McFadden Jr. I was born, raised, and currently reside in West Philadelphia. I have always had a passion for education. In fact, my appreciation and vigorous focus on my own schooling blinded my ability to see the poor educational conditions that were ongoing in my community. Upon completing my Masters in Criminal Justice in 2009, I became a middle school Special Education Co-Teacher at Young Scholars Frederick Douglass School in North Philadelphia. The three years I spent working in that community was an eye opener. It taught me to appreciate the youth even more than I did and that appreciation gave me the motivation to bring change to my community. My current focus is community involvement; specifically to help young men focus on academic and social progress. I am a mentor at Overbrook High School. I mentor young men between ninth and twelfth grade. My mentoring includes social and academic after schools programs, those programs are MAN Up, Homework club, Reading Club, and Fitness Friday.

 

The Big Event

"Any fool can criticize, condemn and complain, and most fools do." – Benjamin Franklin

Location:

Birney Preparatory Academy Charter School

900 Lindley Avenue, Philadelphia, PA 19141

Date: March 16, 2013

Time: 1pm - 4pm

The youth in Philadelphia encounter violence daily on their streets, and in their homes, schools, romantic relationships, and online. However, it is a mistake to see young people only as a problem to be solved. It is time to start seeing them as part of the solution to the crisis of violence in Philadelphia. With your donations, we will host the Philadelphia Youth Project Kick-Off, a community event that will invite community members, businesses, leaders and most importantly, Philadelphia’s youth, out to educate and inform them about educational, employment, and volunteer opportunities.

 

The Philadelphia Youth Project (PYP) will feature speakers and poets who emphasize the importance of non-violence and support the positive progression of the youth in Philadelphia. Along with the speakers and poets there will be companies and organizations that are specifically geared toward supporting the Philadelphia youth. The youth themselves will have the opportunity to sign up with the organizations and/or speak with the companies about volunteer work.

 

If you believe in the power of youth and support their progression, come to The Philadelphia Youth Project (PYP) Kick-Off. To achieve upward mobility in our community is not easy but it can be done. This is our opportunity to achieve upward mobility and change the route of the issues facing the youth.
story_txt:
Thank You!!!
This is a huge thank you to all who participated in and contributed to the very first Philadelphia Youth Project", it was very successful. The generous contributions and assistance from family, friends and my new found associates was also a huge factor to the Philadelphia Youth Project. This was the beginning of many many more events to come. My goal is to be a positive influence to the youth and through the Philadelphia Youth Project, I will be able to fulfill my goal.
 

What is The Philadelphia Youth Project (PYP)? 
The goal of the Philadelphia Youth Project (PYP) is to engage, encourage and educate the youth in Philadelphia through community events, ‘life-building’ workshops and educational events.
 
Why I am starting the Philadelphia Youth Project? 
My name is Christopher McFadden Jr. I was born, raised, and currently reside in West Philadelphia. I have always had a passion for education. In fact, my appreciation and vigorous focus on my own schooling blinded my ability to see the poor educational conditions that were ongoing in my community. Upon completing my Masters in Criminal Justice in 2009, I became a middle school Special Education Co-Teacher at Young Scholars Frederick Douglass School in North Philadelphia. The three years I spent working in that community was an eye opener. It taught me to appreciate the youth even more than I did and that appreciation gave me the motivation to bring change to my community. My current focus is community involvement; specifically to help young men focus on academic and social progress. I am a mentor at Overbrook High School. I mentor young men between ninth and twelfth grade. My mentoring includes social and academic after schools programs, those programs are MAN Up, Homework club, Reading Club, and Fitness Friday.

 
The Big Event
"Any fool can criticize, condemn and complain, and most fools do." – Benjamin Franklin
Location:
Birney Preparatory Academy Charter School
900 Lindley Avenue, Philadelphia, PA 19141
Date: March 16, 2013
Time: 1pm - 4pm
The youth in Philadelphia encounter violence daily on their streets, and in their homes, schools, romantic relationships, and online. However, it is a mistake to see young people only as a problem to be solved. It is time to start seeing them as part of the solution to the crisis of violence in Philadelphia. With your donations, we will host the Philadelphia Youth Project Kick-Off, a community event that will invite community members, businesses, leaders and most importantly, Philadelphia’s youth, out to educate and inform them about educational, employment, and volunteer opportunities.
 
The Philadelphia Youth Project (PYP) will feature speakers and poets who emphasize the importance of non-violence and support the positive progression of the youth in Philadelphia. Along with the speakers and poets there will be companies and organizations that are specifically geared toward supporting the Philadelphia youth. The youth themselves will have the opportunity to sign up with the organizations and/or speak with the companies about volunteer work.
 
If you believe in the power of youth and support their progression, come to The Philadelphia Youth Project (PYP) Kick-Off. To achieve upward mobility in our community is not easy but it can be done. This is our opportunity to achieve upward mobility and change the route of the issues facing the youth.

story:
Our Story

Franklinâ€™s Paine Skatepark Fund is a nonprofit organization dedicated to creating free, skateable spaces; developing programs to get more kids skateboarding instead of playing video games; and making sure that Philadelphiaâ€™s skateboarding culture is appreciated and cultivated by state and local government. We are proud to have been one of the first non-profit advocacy organizations dedicated to skateboarding in the United States and continue to be a leading advocate for skateboarding in the Philadelphia region. We believe that skateboarding is an important component of Philadelphiaâ€™s 21st Century identity, and the need for an organization dedicated to advocating for skateboarders and the development of free, public places to skate has never been greater. 

Gear for Groms (G4G) is our after-school skateboarding program led by professional skateboarder AJ Kohn. G4G takes experienced and professional skateboarders into communities around Philadelphia and connects them with local groms (skate slang for young skaters) to reinforce important life skills - discipline, creativity and teamwork - through skateboarding instruction.


The Project

We need to raise $2,500 for resources for our program that will allow us to add more locations and reach more young skaters.


In supporting our commitment to youth development, safety, and health, we are currently raising funds for the expansion of G4G through our â€œpocketâ€ parks throughout Philadelphia. We are also eager to expand the program to our soon-to-be marquee location, Paineâ€™s Park, which will be a mixed-use public space, designed with skateboarding in mind, set along the Schuylkill Banks adjacent to the Philadelphia Museum of Art.  Since Paineâ€™s Park was first conceptualized in 2002, it has become a model for a new kind of dialogue between skateboarding, landscape architecture, and city planning, where space is designed to accommodate skateboarding as an important energizing force behind the life and movement of public space.  Click here for a recent press release issued on the status of the project. We are excited to bring G4G to what will certainly become an internationally recognized skateboarding and mixed-use public park and your donation will help us expand G4G to Paine's Park.


The Need

  • Many kids spend between 20-25 hours a week alone and unsupervised after school.
  • Kids who are unsupervised after school are far more likely to use alcohol, tobacco and drugs.
  • Kids commit -and are victims of- crime in the after school hours, with the peak hour between 3-4 p.m.
  • Many kids are not active - 30% of kids between the ages of 6 and 19 are overweight (15% are obese) - and this can, in part, be attributed to the fact that they are alone in the afternoon to snack, watch TV, and play video games.

The Impact

  • Students who participate in after school programs show gains in school achievement, attendance, and graduation rates.
  • After school programs reduce the use of drugs, tobacco and alcohol among adolescents.
  • Involvement in skateboarding promotes discipline, creativity and development of work ethic among youth.
  • Skateboarding positivity impacts social development in youth and is a common language between people of different ages, cultures and backgrounds.

story:
Retail Management for unemployed youngsters
                                 
 
 
When we started to work in Latvia in 2009 the country was slowly recovering from the economical crisis. Our goal to create a professional structure for vocational education for Retail was rejected by many people.
 
Unemployment in Latvia is still over 12%. But the youth unemployment is over 25%.
Many young people left the country. Many of them left without a proper education.

There is a present and growing need in Latvia for employees trained in basic communication skills to support the growing service sectors. Low income young adults want to be upskilled, but are unable to pay the training costs upfront. The result is that millions of young adults are unnecessarily trapped in poverty: they are confined to temporary jobs in the informal sector and earn less than US$15 a day.

Private and Non-Profit Vocational Education and Training (VET) Institutes are able to transform the lives of these young adults by upskilling them and placing them in well paid jobs in the service sectors. A one month course in communication skills costs approximately $300, but enables a graduate to increase his/her earnings six-fold and become a member of the lower working middle-class.

Strong demand for VET training exists, but growth of VET providers is limited by access to financing. Students typically have limited savings to fund tuition and corporate employers are unwilling to pay for tuition upfront despite their need for trained workers. Consequently, VET schools rely mostly on donations, which severely constrains the school’s ability to achieve scale and impact.

We have developed a new way to fund vocational training: we pay for students’ tuition upfront and upon completion of their training, students enter paid internships.

How we will choose the participants?

We will choose by following criteria's:

1. Unemployment level in Family

2. Duration of Unemployment

3. CV and Motivationletter

What we are raising money for

We are raising money for 100 Scholarships. Each Scholarship costs 300$. But you can donate for sure also less or more.
 
$7000 for books and materials
 
$4000 for trips to Retail companies
 
$10000 for products, tests and certifications
 
$9000 for teachers sallery

This will benefit to youn unemployed people in Latvia who would otherwise have no access to vocational education. 

Why are we raising funds?

We are passionate about education and wanted to empower young people by providing them with access to quality education. We want to pass on our legacy to them so they are able to realise their own opportunities and dreams.

Our dream for Latvia is to build vocational excellence in Retail.

We can`t do this alone. We need your help.

So how can you help?  Firstly, by making a donation. Anything you give, no matter how small, will have an incredible ripple effect for years to come.For each donation, we have a unique way to thank you (see our perks).

Secondly, you can help by spreading the word about our unique project.

Thank you.

story:
Busting Breast Cancer: 7 Simple Steps to protect our daughters from this unnecessary disease 

This is the first book to offer women healthy, significant and inexpensive ways to help stop breast cancer before it can start.

Please purchase the book today & help me finish the manuscript  in the coming three months.   

The international research exists. Each woman who develops breast cancer carries her own unique cocktail of toxins and toxic assaults in her body.

U.S. breast cancer rates are climbing faster each year than ever before because most women don't know about these 7 Simple Steps that can help stop much of this unnecessary cancer.   

 

Why are U.S. Breast Cancer Rates Increasing?

Our grandmothers and great grandmothers didn't get breast cancer in the huge numbers we are seeing today; a breast cancer germ did not recently   fall from the sky.

Instead, modern day lifestyle habits and products continue to affect women's bodies. causing invasive breast cancer rates to rise by 12 percent a year in younger women under 45,  and by 6 percent a year in women 65 & older.

These increasing invasive breast cancer rates are unacceptable.   

 

Why hasn't this book been done before?

There are no big profits in natural prevention.

Most medically trained folks in the U.S. can only make money once  women get sick. Pharmaceutical companies make more money when more women get sick and  successful cancer centers usually become more profitable when more women need their services.

Few medical professionals or institutions have the time to teach women inexpensive  lifestyle habits that will help us avoid getting that first  invasive breast cancer diagnosis.   

This means that women (and those who love us) are the only folks with the self -interest and the power to help stop breast cancer before it can start. 

 

What are some of these research-based steps found in Busting Breast Cancer?

  • Raise your Vitamin D3 blood level to 50-80 ng/ml using safe tanning and Vitamin D3 supplement. KNOW your vitamin D3 number!!!!
  • Avoid birth control drugs & try a hormone-free IUD or have a tubal ligation instead. 
  • Eat at least 7 cancer-blocking foods and supplements each day. 

 

Do any doctors support Busting Breast Cancer's 7 Simple Steps? 

 

Dr Stanislaw Burzynski M.D., Ph.D.

Dear Susan: 

I learned about your new organization and forthcoming book on breast cancer. Please let me know how I can help you make this project successful.

Stanislawy Burzynski M.D., Ph.D. 

Burzynski Clinic, Houston Texas

May 24,2012

                            ************************

Dr. Susan Love M.D.

You find people less wanting to think about birth control pills, hormone replacement therapy and fertility drugs than about pesticides, bras and deodorant.

Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, 4th Edition, Susan Love, M.D. 

 

Dr. Michael Holick, M.D., Ph.D.

The population of the world has been brainwashed by the American Academy of Dermatology and the sunscreen industry, for 30 years, with the unrelenting message that you should never be exposed to direct sunlight because it is going to cause serious skin cancer and death.”

Michael Holick, MD Professor of Medicine, Physiology and Biophysics at Boston University School of Medicine

 

Dr Cedric Garland, Ph.D.

Dr Garland and his coauthors have developed a novel cancer theory, the Devolution hypothesis, based mainly on their research on the role of vitamin D in reducing the risk of cancer and improving healthy survival of cancer patients. 

Dr Cedric Garland, Ph.D. Moores Cancer Center, University of California at San Diego

 

This is a Win-Win Project

Proceeds from Busting Breast Cancer book sales will be used to fund Busting Breast Cancer, a non-profit educational organization and Embracing the World charities, as we help millions more women in the U.S. and around the world learn inexpensive and significant ways to  help stop breast cancer before it can start. 

Please participate in this Indiegogo Campaign now. By purchasing one or more copies of Busting Breast Cancer today,  you will  give me the needed funds to complete the book in the next twelve weeks. I cannot do this without your help today. Together we will complete this book and save lives as we teach women 7 Simple Steps to help protect ourselves from this unecessary disease. 

Did you know?

Very few breast cancer foundations support natural prevention projects

Susan G Komen for the Cure, the American Cancer Society and many other national  breast cancer foundations usually limit their grants to detection and treatment programs. This means that  non profit educational work or a book project,  such as Busting Breast Cancer, that focuses exclusively on natural ways for women to help stop breast cancer before it starts, are ineligible for Komen and Cancer Society funding. 

 

The Author

Susan Wadia-Ells is founding director of the National Breast Cancer Prevention Project/Busting Breast Cancer The five year old non-profit offers educational programs, including a website, blog, articles and workshops that  translate international research on the known, probable and possible causes of breast cancer into everyday language that all women can use to help stop breast cancer before it starts.

Susan has been a life-long national change agent. Working at Polaroid, the Fortune 200 instant photography giant, as a young administrator during the 1970's, Susan quickly organized  women employees and pressured corporate management to offer equal benefits and equal pay, along with goals and timetables to include women in skilled trades, sales, manufacturing, finance and marketing jobs at all levels.

When the Wall Street Journal, The New York Times and Harvard Business School soon began calling Susan to ask, "What do U.S. corporations think about this woman's issue or that?",  Susan began to understand that national social change and individual power are all about being in the right place at the right time; moving forward with a plan, and having the right support around you 24-7. Her work at Polaroid is described in Not Servants. Not Machines: Office Workers Speak Out  by Jean Tepperman, Beacon Press, 1975 and Networking:The Great New Way for Women to Get Ahead, by Mary-Scott Welch, Harcourt Brace, 1980. 

After leaving Polaroid, Susan received a graduate degree in politics and energy economics from the Fletcher School at Tufts University and  a Ph.D. in Women Studies from the Union Institute and University. She taught at Lesley University and created The Wise Ones Conference Group with Joan Loomis Hastings, beginning with a conference celebrating the 5th anniversary of the watershed, Women's Ways of Knowing Study. 

Susan is the creator and contributing editor of The Adoption Reader: Birth Mothers, Adoptive Mothers and Adopted Daughters Tell Their Stories, published by Seal Press.  She also helped edit  The Economic Report of the People, by  Juliet Schor, Samuel Bowles and other members at the Center for Popular Economics, published by South End Press.

Susan's Honest Health and political columns have appeared in the Brattleboro Reformer (VT), the Gloucester Daily Times (MA), the Cape Cod Times (MA), the Keene Sentinel (NH), Sojourner (MA), the Worcester Telegram and Gazette, the Eagle Tribune (MA), Management Review (American Management Association), Society & Innovation and In These Times and in various on-line journals.

campaign_city: Manchester by the Sea, United States

story:
Dear friends & family, near and far:

After studying with a small music school in rural Brazil last spring, I promised the school's directors that I would use my privilege and all of the resources the U.S. has to offer to help raise funds for them to buy air conditioning for the school's classrooms! Help me help them, by donating to this fundraiser! Just click "FUND THIS PROJECT" above to donate in less than 5 minutes.

I know you are probably sick of getting asked to donate money to various groups. This fundraiser, however, is different, for 2 main reasons:

1) the money does not go through a third party NGO or institution -- it goes straight from our hands to the hands of the school's directors in Iguatu.
2) the money will be helping fulfill a need that the students of the school themselves identified! Air conditioning is not something I THINK the school needs -- it is a need students and staff expressed directly to me.

If you have questions, please contact me personally or email me at: emnewton@pugetsound.edu. See below for the story of my involvement with the school.

I would really appreciate your help in this. The money will mean so much to the Escola de Musica and to my friends in Iguatu.

Peace & love,
Elizabeth


Background

As most of you know, this last spring I studied abroad for 4 months in Brazil. The final month of this was an independent research project on a topic of my choosing. How did I decide what to do, you ask?


One Sunday morning I was reading the local newspaper. My Portuguese was broken (at best), but I nonetheless was able to get through most of the major news articles. One in particular caught my eye, and I read on. The article was covering the Escola de Música Popular Humberto Teixeira (Humberto Teixeira School of Popular Music), a newly built music school in the interior, or rural, part of the state I was living in, in a small city called Iguatu. It was a popular-music school funded by the government, which offered free music lessons to anyone who wanted them. Already, it had 400 students, and a wait-list of dozens. I was intrigued. After speaking with my academic director, she contacted the director of the school, and within days I was set to do my independent study with the school.


For all of May 2010, I lived in Iguatu, a city of 100,000 people, and spent every day working at the Escola de Música. I sat in on classes, got know the students and teachers, and took a few music lessons myself! (Who knew I would be so terrible at playing the accordion?) I also got to know members of the Iguatu community and was welcomed with open arms by everyone I met.


As I worked at the school, I was impressed by the successes of the school in just a few short months of operation. With support from the community, over 400 kids and adults in Iguatu now have access to music education. This has helped keep kids off of the streets and has given them a place to feel like they belong. It has also helped to preserve important cultural traditions in Iguatu that are currently being eroded by Western influence.


All this said, the school still struggles financially, with only limited funding from the government. The facilities are very nice, but very simple, with only 1 CD player that teachers must share between 8 classrooms. There is not enough money to buy instruments for students to rent, so students cannot practice at home.


Main Need: Air Conditioning!

Iguatu is one of the hottest cities in Brazil. It is located in the dry, "sertao" (desert) region of Brazil, which gets extremely little rainfall and frequently experiences drought. Every day of the year, it is at least 90 degrees F outside with 70-80% humidity.


Most buildings and homes do not have air conditioning, simply because it is not financially feasible. In the School of Music, the main office had air conditioning, but no other classrooms did. The classes had only small ceiling fans that hardly did any good at all.


As a result, during music classes, students would take breaks at least every 15 minutes or so to drink water and cool off. This was very distracting and at times unproductive.


When I asked students and staff individually what the main need of the school is, they each replied, without exception, "Air conditioning!!"


At the end of my time in Iguatu, I promised the staff at the school that I would use the extreme wealth of the United States to help the school.


Here in the US we routinely take a comfortable climate, heating & A/C, and easy access to appropriate clothing for granted. If we are ever in a building in the winter without heating, or our school's air conditioning suddenly stopped working in late August, we would immediately complain and demand that something be done. In Iguatu, students deal with this heat every day -- and no, they never "get used to it."


What We Need

US$600 will buy 1 air conditioner for the school. I would ideally like to give them more money, but I am trying to be realistic. 


1 air conditioner will make a big difference at the school. It will make the school day more comfortable, and encourage more students to continue attending the school, thus building community and diverting kids from engaging in less productive activities like drugs and violence.


Perhaps more importantly, our gift to the kids of Iguatu will be a valuable step toward cultural cooperation and a symbol of our support of their school. I know that most of you recognize the importance of music education. It is not, however, just important in the US -- it is important everywhere!


I know the directors are not expecting me to keep my promise. Unfortunately, individuals in developing countries are often used to plans falling through and donor groups failing to deliver. Think about how powerful it will be when the students at the Escola de Musica realize that dozens of US citizens were thinking just about them!


Your donation, in any amount, will help so much! 100% of funds donated, minus fees necessary for wiring the money to my contacts in Iguatu, will be wired DIRECTLY to the school to be used by the directors of the school themselves. There is no third party. You can feel confident in donating to this fundraiser that your money will have direct impact on the lives of those I met in Iguatu.


How to Help

Donate whatever amount you can! Think about what you spend money on every week. Coffee, beer, sandwiches, gas, expensive shampoo, and much, much more! I'm not trying to guilt trip you -- just trying to encourage you to to divert a small amount of this spending each week into this fundraiser.


Donating is so easy. Like, it could seriously not be any easier. You don't even have to register. Just hit "FUND THIS PROJECT" above, enter your credit card information, and you're done. Within 3 minutes!!! The website is secure and safe (I have used it before and have donated myself to other fundraisers.)


I am not naive in thinking that buying an air conditioning unit or two will solve the multitude of social problems that affect our world. I know, however, that this is a small, easy thing we can all do together to help make a school doing great things do even more good.

Sincerely,

Elizabeth


For further information:

Check out the pictures I have posted under the "Gallery" tab above!

The City of Iguatu website: http://www.iguatu.ce.gov.br/

An interview I did with a local Iguatu news source: http://www.iguatu.net/novo/wordpress/?p=5246
story_txt:
Dear friends & family, near and far:After studying with a small music school in rural Brazil last spring, I promised the school's directors that I would use my privilege and all of the resources the U.S. has to offer to help raise funds for them to buy air conditioning for the school's classrooms! Help me help them, by donating to this fundraiser! Just click "FUND THIS PROJECT" above to donate in less than 5 minutes.I know you are probably sick of getting asked to donate money to various groups. This fundraiser, however, is different, for 2 main reasons:1) the money does not go through a third party NGO or institution -- it goes straight from our hands to the hands of the school's directors in Iguatu.2) the money will be helping fulfill a need that the students of the school themselves identified! Air conditioning is not something I THINK the school needs -- it is a need students and staff expressed directly to me.If you have questions, please contact me personally or email me at: emnewton@pugetsound.edu. See below for the story of my involvement with the school.I would really appreciate your help in this. The money will mean so much to the Escola de Musica and to my friends in Iguatu.Peace & love,Elizabeth
Background

As most of you know, this last spring I studied abroad for 4 months in Brazil. The final month of this was an independent research project on a topic of my choosing. How did I decide what to do, you ask?

One Sunday morning I was reading the local newspaper. My Portuguese was broken (at best), but I nonetheless was able to get through most of the major news articles. One in particular caught my eye, and I read on. The article was covering the Escola de Música Popular Humberto Teixeira (Humberto Teixeira School of Popular Music), a newly built music school in the interior, or rural, part of the state I was living in, in a small city called Iguatu. It was a popular-music school funded by the government, which offered free music lessons to anyone who wanted them. Already, it had 400 students, and a wait-list of dozens. I was intrigued. After speaking with my academic director, she contacted the director of the school, and within days I was set to do my independent study with the school.

For all of May 2010, I lived in Iguatu, a city of 100,000 people, and spent every day working at the Escola de Música. I sat in on classes, got know the students and teachers, and took a few music lessons myself! (Who knew I would be so terrible at playing the accordion?) I also got to know members of the Iguatu community and was welcomed with open arms by everyone I met.

 As I worked at the school, I was impressed by the successes of the school in just a few short months of operation. With support from the community, over 400 kids and adults in Iguatu now have access to music education. This has helped keep kids off of the streets and has given them a place to feel like they belong. It has also helped to preserve important cultural traditions in Iguatu that are currently being eroded by Western influence.

All this said, the school still struggles financially, with only limited funding from the government. There is not enough money to buy instruments for students to rent, so students cannot practice at home.

As a result, during music classes, students would take breaks at least every 15 minutes or so to drink water and cool off. This was very distracting and at times unproductive.

When I asked students and staff individually what the main need of the school is, they each replied, without exception, "Air conditioning!!"

At the end of my time in Iguatu, I promised the staff at the school that I would use the extreme wealth of the United States to help the school. 

Here in the US we routinely take a comfortable climate, heating & A/C, and easy access to appropriate clothing for granted. If we are ever in a building in the winter without heating, or our school's air conditioning suddenly stopped working in late August, we would immediately complain and demand that something be done. In Iguatu, students deal with this heat every day -- and no, they never "get used to it."

Perhaps more importantly, our gift to the kids of Iguatu will be a valuable step toward cultural cooperation and a symbol of our support of their school. I know that most of you recognize the importance of music education. It is not, however, just important in the US -- it is important everywhere!

I know the directors are not expecting me to keep my promise. Unfortunately, individuals in developing countries are often used to plans falling through and donor groups failing to deliver. Think about how powerful it will be when the students at the Escola de Musica realize that dozens of US citizens were thinking just about them!

Your donation, in any amount, will help so much! 100% of funds donated, minus fees necessary for wiring the money to my contacts in Iguatu, will be wired DIRECTLY to the school to be used by the directors of the school themselves. story:
Did you know that in 1921 the British Football Association ruled that Football was unfit for women to play? Did you also know that this ban lasted until the 1970s? Women’s football has been relegated to the side-lines of the history of football and we need your help to do this.

Eastside Community Heritage is an Archive and Heritage charity based in East London and we are passionate about promoting the hidden histories of East London We celebrate the lives of ordinary people who have extraordinary stories to tell.

 

Women’s Football: The East London Story -

An Exhibition for Women’s History Month 2017

 

This exhibition will celebrate the lives and stories that the pioneering women of East London have made to Britain’s favourite game. The East London story has been in the shadow of the North Eastern teams and we want to uncover and celebrate the role that East Londoner have had on the game.

Women’s football has had a long and controversial history in London. The first public football game was played in Crouch End in 1895 which attracted an audience of over 10,000. Throughout the war the women’s game became so popular that it began to overtake the men’s game in popularity. Soon after, it was banned.  The fifty-year FA ban pushed back the women’s game, and is a legacy we see today.

Help us celebrate Women’s History Month in 2017 and tell the story of Women’s football in the East End.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

We need £2,000 to help fund the production of and exhibition and run events across East London. This will include:

  • A touring exhibition about Women’s Football in East London that will tour across East London throughout March and the months after, with an exhibition launch event (£1200 cost for designing and printing the exhibition and to help fund the launch)
  • Deliver a programme of youth workshops across East London in March aimed at empowering young girls to explore history and football in community centres (£400 for costs, materials and resources)
  • Run community workshops to promote women’s history and the impact the women of East London have had on Football (£400 for costs, materials and resources)

 

The Impact

 

This project will celebrate the history of East London women and the contributions they have made in football. Women continue to face discrimination in football and we want to address this head on. We want to empower young girls to explore their own heritage and take ownership of playing football.  With this exhibition we not only want to uncover the history of Women’s football, but celebrate it too.

 

Risk and Challenges

 

We have a tight deadline and a small budget to make this project a reality if we are to deliver this project by Women’s History Month in March 2017. We need to:

  • Design and print the exhibition
  • Organise venues and make arrangements for refreshments
  • Develop workshop materials that will empower young girls to play football.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

You may not be able to contribute financially, but you can certainly help us by spreading the word and making some noise about our campaign. Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Also, if you think you, or anyone you know, would be interested in being interviewed for this project, and so contributing material for the workshops and exhibition, please contact Eastside Community Heritage.

You can also read some fun facts about our project on the popular social news website, Buzzfeed. Link: https://www.buzzfeed.com/paulech/13-things-abou...

Thank you for your support!

story:
What's the Deal?

Let's keep it simple: We want to bring back t-shirts and keep them cheap AND we want some spare cash to overall the Suburban.

So any of you who might want a shirt, or to gift a shirt, buy a shirt.  We'll take the money to the mechanic and get ourselves all set for the road.  Any extra funds will go towards travel expenses.

Why do you need my money?

Since we have chosen to limit our series to COMPLETING WWI before we go further, Othais has had to put in a LOT of work just to find the pieces we need.  Travel is becoming a bigger and bigger part of that.  Now the main show is fully in the black but with a take-home of less that $2 an hour, 0-man isn't exactly swimming in personal savings.



What is with the Suburban?

Earlier this year we went to Springfield and came away with a LOT of great material and wonderful new friends and associates.  We'd like to do more of that in general.  Now for this trip we bummed an Equinox and it barely fit 3 of us and our lightbox + gear.  We'd like to add extra helpers to more efficiently use our limited time at museums and gear to allow us to photograph and video more while on site.  But that little SUV wasn't going to take any more and honestly we were in pain for days after due to "ergonomics."

So the team talked it over and from personal funds we bought an old Suburban.  We bought it cheap, real cheap.  We just want to give it a good overhaul and a rebuilt transmission before we drive several thousand miles on it.  With this vehicle we can fit full gear and 5 people, or maybe even 8 if we invest in a roof rack.  No trickiness with getting through the airport with a ton of gear, etc.  Plus we can drive for days with way less back pain. 

So what do I get?

Immediately you get your shirt(s).  In the long run you get live shows from Springfield, tons of excellent images of exceedingly rare pieces like the Italian OVP SMG and US Pederson Device, and more machine gun episodes.

Shirt Sizing

story:
Victor Marroquin, UC Riverside (FIF 2015): “I am a Mexican-Guatemalan American, the first in my mixed status family to be born in the U.S. and a bisexual immigrant rights activist.  I have been a victim of hatred for my identity.  I live in between Koreatown and East Hollywood, communities of Los Angeles that face the most immigrant status challenges as a result of the current broken immigration system." 

Dear supporter:

The assault on public and higher education by the Trump administration has made first in the family funding even more urgent.  As the administration prepares to gut what remains of public K-12 education, schools around the nation will see lower college-going rates among their most vulnerable youth populations. With high rates of push-out and policing in Los Angeles schools, undocumented, foster care, homeless and LGBTQ students face even greater odds in their quest for college admission and graduation.  With your renewed support, we hope to award L.A. area students of color another round of $1000 scholarships to assist with their books, tuition, housing and other living expenses.  Our 2013-2016 scholars are now at USC, UCLA, UC Riverside, Cal State University Long Beach, Babson College, University of North Texas, UC Merced, El Camino College, UC Berkeley, Amherst College, Cal State Dominguez and Carleton College.  Listen to their stories and please circulate our campaign widely!  

Black Skeptics Los Angeles

Nyallah Noah, University of Southern California (FIF 2015): "It wasn’t until this past year that I realized how important feminism, civil rights and LGBT rights were to me.  Born and raised in Los Angeles, being a seventeen year-old African American lesbian has been tough to be quite honest…I do not understand why in 2015 we are still fighting for civil rights for different minority groups, I do not understand why it has taken years for same sex marriage to be a legal act; nor do I understand why every day there are black men, women and children who are being killed because apparently the color of their skin is just as deadly as a weapon.”

story:
What are you doing?

Allow me to tell you that through our mission which is, "Creating Friendships, Fostering Excellence, Developing Champions" I am starting a Forensics (Speech and Debate) league for students in grades 3-5. Overall, it is imperative that it presents itself just as the more well known leagues like the NSDA or CFL. There will be 8 categories pertinent to Competitive theatre public speaking and Debate. This is starting in Wisconsin with Forensics clubs that I am piloting at the elementary schools in Brookfield, WI. If things go according to plan, our first state competition will be in 2019 with plans for a national competition in 2025. 

Who are you?

I probably should have introduced myself earlier, I forget that I am not famous...yet :)  Here is my bio: So, My name is Dontae Hill AKA "The Forensics Guy" on social media. I am a Speech and Debate coach from Wisconsin with a passion for making this activity a priority for all. (As you can see with this project, I love Forensics SOOO MUCH! I want Forensics to be the first word your baby says lbvs)  I have been involved with the activity since the 8th grade when my English teacher Ms. Gonzalez found a way to channel my talkative spirit in class into an after-school activity that will never cease giving me joy. I am currently utilizing my social media presence to inspire more to be involved within the Speech and Debate community as well as creating content to help students, coaches, and judges improve success at the activity. This is my 6th year of coaching, and my 13th year of being involved with the activity altogether. 

Why are you doing this? 

Because... Forensics-Duh!

What will our contribution help with. 

Your contribution will help us start to pay for things like office space, marketing, materials, coaches and a venue for the state competition!

The Impact

It goes without saying but if you can help make a difference in these student lives like my coaches and mentor did for me. The impact is priceless...

Risks & Challenges

There are always risk when it comes to putting effort into a dream, the biggest risk is not trying...

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate to this campaign, you can still play a vital role in helping spread the word about the campaign.  Use IndieGoGo's social media tools and tell people you know about this campaign. Supporters of the campaign can live outside of WI. SO SPREAD THE WORD!!!

story:
hi, im stasha~ im a 33 y/o single mom from california.       

i started "Healing with Beats" to offer  vibration, sound and musical healing to children all across the world.

I have integrated 11 yrs of dance/choreography training,  11 yrs of music production/singing experience, and 11 yrs of energetic healing therapy into fun little healing"pow-wow's"for children in need. 

Healing with Beats will teach the benefits of sound healing so that they will not only be able to heal themselves, but also their friends and family. 

Think about how great a song can make you feel when you are down? It is a scientific fact that music heals! My healing "pow wow's" will be focused in three parts:

1- DIY Music Instrument Making: Creating DIY Instruments from Recycled and Repurposed Materials (The possibilities are ENDLESS!)

2- Making Music from the Instruments they have created: 

(I will be recording these sessions for a CD I plan to release upon completion of the project)

3- Dancing, Singing & Performing their songs as a group: 

(I will be recording these performances for a DVD I will be creating)

*A PORTION OF THE PROCEEDS FROM DVD SALES WILL GO DIRECTLY BACK TO THE CHARITIES & GROUPS THAT ARE INVOLVED!

*A PORTION  OF THE PROCEEDS FROM THE CD SALES WILL GO DIRECTLY BACK TO HEALING WITH BEATS TO KEEP THE PROJECT GOING!     

I HOPE THAT YOU WILL HELP US HEAL WITH BEATS, 

WE CANNOT DO THIS WITHOUT YOUR HELP, 

DONATIONS ARE GREATLY APPRECIATED!

XO 

Blessings and Beats ~ 

Stasha Colin, CEO

HEALING WITH BEATS

WHAT I NEED YOUR HELP WITH:

1- PLANE TICKETS & OTHER TRANSPORTATION TO EACH CITY/ COUNTRY.

(AIR MILE DONATIONS ARE ALSO ACCEPTED!)

2- DIY INSTRUMENTS 

(I PREFER TO MAKE INSTRUMENTS OUT OF RECYCLED OBJECTS, BUT THERE WILL STILL BE SOME COSTS FOR MATERIALS, ETC. IF YOU HAVE ITEMS YOU CAN DONATE, THAT IS GREATLY APPRECIATED AS WELL!)

3- DVD & CD COSTS

(PRODUCTION, EDITING & DISTRIBUTION OF EACH)

I WILL BE MAKING A VIDEO DIARY OF OUR PROGRESS, AS WELL AS A NEWSLETTER THAT I WILL SEND OUT TO EVERYONE THAT DONATES.

ENGLAND IS MY FIRST DESTINATION, AFTER THAT I WILL GO WHEREVER THE UNIVERSE CALLS ME TO! PLEASE SEND SUGGESTIONS OF PROGRAMS THAT CAN USE MY HELP. 

YOU CAN SEND ALL INQUIRIES TO MY EMAIL:

healingwithbeats@gmail.com

CHECK FOR UPDATES & OTHER INFO ON MY WEBSITE:

healingwithbeats.us
story_txt:
hi, im stasha~ im a 33 y/o single mom from california.       
i started "Healing with Beats" to offer  vibration, sound and musical healing to children all across the world.
I have integrated 11 yrs of dance/choreography training,  11 yrs of music production/singing experience, and 11 yrs of energetic healing therapy into fun little healing"pow-wow's"for children in need. 
Healing with Beats will teach the benefits of sound healing so that they will not only be able to heal themselves, but also their friends and family. 
Think about how great a song can make you feel when you are down? It is a scientific fact that music heals! My healing "pow wow's" will be focused in three parts:
1- DIY Music Instrument Making: Creating DIY Instruments from Recycled and Repurposed Materials (The possibilities are ENDLESS!)
2- Making Music from the Instruments they have created: 
(I will be recording these sessions for a CD I plan to release upon completion of the project)
3- Dancing, Singing & Performing their songs as a group: 
(I will be recording these performances for a DVD I will be creating)
*A PORTION OF THE PROCEEDS FROM DVD SALES WILL GO DIRECTLY BACK TO THE CHARITIES & GROUPS THAT ARE INVOLVED!
*A PORTION  OF THE PROCEEDS FROM THE CD SALES WILL GO DIRECTLY BACK TO HEALING WITH BEATS TO KEEP THE PROJECT GOING!     
I HOPE THAT YOU WILL HELP US HEAL WITH BEATS, 
WE CANNOT DO THIS WITHOUT YOUR HELP, 
DONATIONS ARE GREATLY APPRECIATED!
XO 
Blessings and Beats ~ 
Stasha Colin, CEO
HEALING WITH BEATS
WHAT I NEED YOUR HELP WITH:
1- PLANE TICKETS & OTHER TRANSPORTATION TO EACH CITY/ COUNTRY.
(AIR MILE DONATIONS ARE ALSO ACCEPTED!)
2- DIY INSTRUMENTS 
(I PREFER TO MAKE INSTRUMENTS OUT OF RECYCLED OBJECTS, BUT THERE WILL STILL BE SOME COSTS FOR MATERIALS, ETC. IF YOU HAVE ITEMS YOU CAN DONATE, THAT IS GREATLY APPRECIATED AS WELL!)
3- DVD & CD COSTS
(PRODUCTION, EDITING & DISTRIBUTION OF EACH)
I WILL BE MAKING A VIDEO DIARY OF OUR PROGRESS, AS WELL AS A NEWSLETTER THAT I WILL SEND OUT TO EVERYONE THAT DONATES.
ENGLAND IS MY FIRST DESTINATION, AFTER THAT I WILL GO WHEREVER THE UNIVERSE CALLS ME TO! PLEASE SEND SUGGESTIONS OF PROGRAMS THAT CAN USE MY HELP. 
YOU CAN SEND ALL INQUIRIES TO MY EMAIL:
healingwithbeats@gmail.com
CHECK FOR UPDATES & OTHER INFO ON MY WEBSITE:
healingwithbeats.us

story:
The Ubushobozi Story

Two years ago, my pals Betsy and Dolinda went to Rwanda and fell in love with the Ubushobozi Project, a non-profit group dedicated to empowering orphaned teenage girls from the village of Gashingiro. They posted pictures from their two visits on Facebook and shared stories of courageous young women triumphing over violence and poverty.

From Ubushobozi's website: Ubushobozi Project is a non-profit organization started by Jeanne Siporin, Alan Siporin and Laura Boyea in September 2008... Through education and skills training Ubushobozi seeks to end the cycle of poverty they have experienced throughout their young lives.

Through the generosity of our dedicated donors, Ubushobozi provides each student with a sewing machine (which they then own), sewing lessons, fabric and an outlet for selling their creations. In addition, they are provided with a weekly stipend, nutritious meals (of their choosing) and English, mathematics, computers and basic life skills. Health issues are addressed through routine HIV testing and all girls are provided with medical insurance to seek quality, professional care.

The participants are accepted into Ubushobozi by peer recommendation and approval by the all project members, staff and advisers based on these criteria: unable to attend school due to lack of fees, orphaned or head of household, at risk due to poverty. 100% of Ubushobozi’s participants reside in dwellings with no electricity or running water. Through the Ubushobozi Project they are able to purchase candles or lanterns and clean water on a steady basis.

The project just welcomed its ninth student, 15-year-old Margaret and her 5-month-old baby, Eric. Are you crying yet?

My Story

Last June, Betsy, Dolinda, and some New York-based volunteers held an Ubushobozi fundraiser at a restaurant in Brooklyn. Ubushobozi bags were available for sale (I bought several, despite being recently unemployed), and prizes were raffled; it was a blast. At the end of the evening, one of the volunteers announced that the fundraiser, a bunch of middle-class New Yorkers kicking in a $20 suggested donation and drinking beer, raised enough money to bring another girl into the project. Just a few thousand dollars--a couple of months’ rent in New York City--was going to change the life of another girl living in poverty. I was blown away (and crying in my seltzer).

Since then, the money from the fundraiser, plus private donations have enabled the project to start a vegetable garden and buy chickens, purchase national health insurance for each student, staff member, and their immediate families and household members, AND allow another student into the project. Ubushobozi has gone from two students and one volunteer in 2008 to nine students and eight full-time Rwandan staff members in just three years.

In November 2010, I signed up to sell some of my handicrafts at an eco-fair in Long Island City to supplement my freelance editor’s income. A couple of weeks before the show I was scrambling for stock when I had a brilliant idea. I should sell Ubushobozi bags too! Those girls had been haunting me since the fundraiser. Plus, I always got so many compliments on my bag; I knew they would be the hit of the fair.

Betsy was thrilled with the idea. We met at my favorite lunch spot, where she gave me the bags and I made a confession. “I’ve been stalking you and Dlo and the girls on Facebook for like a year.”

“Before you know it, you’ll be going to Rwanda to teach the girls to crochet,” she said.

I almost burst into tears. Or maybe I did.

“I could do that?”

“They would LOVE it!” she insisted. I was stunned, and those words imprinted on my brain.

Shoppers at the craft fair purchased nearly all of the bags in just a few short hours. People loved hearing about the girls and knowing that the money would go directly into the project. The whole time I kept thinking, Can I do this? Can I go to Rwanda? Yes, I can go to Rwanda.

Betsy and I saw each other a few weeks later. “I can’t stop thinking about what you said. Who do I need to speak to about making this happen?" I asked.

“Our volunteer coordinator,” she deadpanned.

“Super. Can you put us in touch?"

"Sure." She looked like she might burst. "It's me."

So here we are, and I’m going to Rwanda. My whole life, I’ve secretly wanted to join the Peace Corp, but I figured an actor/writer/crafter/vegetarian blogger wouldn’t be much help setting up irrigation systems or fighting malaria outbreaks. While that may be true, it turns out I have something to offer the girls of Ubushobozi Project.

Craftstory

According to Betsy, the Ubushobozi girls want to learn EVERYTHING. So, I intend to teach them everything I know: food and crafts.

Nutrition: Meat is expensive and scarce in Rwanda. The girls eat a mostly starch-based diet of potatoes, rice, and sorghum with fresh vegetables from their home gardens. I’ll be using my years of frugal vegetarian cooking and eating (!) experience to show them how to get the most nutrition from what’s available.

Knit and crochet: Ruhengeri and Gashingiro are in the mountain region of Rwanda. The nip in the evening air warrants cool weather wear like scarves, hats, and sweaters, so knitting and crocheting will be handy skills for the girls to have. Crochet bags and dish clothes can also be useful additions to the current Ubushobozi sales offering.

Embroidery: The girls are pros at machine sewing and make beautiful garments and accessories. With basic hand embroidery skills, like back stitch, chain stitch, and the French knot, they can start to embellish their clothes and accessories and perhaps create art to sell, as well.

One of the girls has an injury that prevents her from operating the sewing machine's foot pedals. Learning these hand crafts will be invaluable skills for her. We’ll also dabble in the stencil arts, courtesy of graphic design star Ed Roth.

Your Story

I need about $3,000 to go to Rwanda. Until two weeks ago, I was a semi-employed writer/editor trying to save for this trip, but mostly just getting by like everyone else. Now that I have a full-time job, the savings is slowly starting to rebound, but not quickly enough to keep the Rwanda plan in motion.

Your contributions will provide me with round-trip airfare from New York-JFK to Kigali, Rwanda (approximately $2,600), plus minor but necessary expenses during my 10-day volunteer commitment in late July-early August. I’ll be staying at the Ubushobozi Project’s house, so my only lodging costs will be purchasing a mattress ($80) from the local market. The rest of the money raised (roughly $300) will go to purchasing craft supplies, like knitting needles, crochet hooks, embroidery needles, yarn, floss, fabric, and paint for the girls. I am working on corporate donations for supplies and have a call out to knit and crochet designers for an exclusive Ubushobozi bag the girls can sell.

Any money raised that is not spent on supplies will be donated to directly to the Ubushobozi Project for the girls’ benefit. There will be occasions for travel within Rwanda, and I can't wait to explore the country, visit the girls' homes, and maybe spot a mountain gorilla, but I will pay for all of my own personal expenses and sight-seeing opportunities.

Everyone who makes a donation will receive my eternal gratitude, as well as some tasty, homemade perks. Check out the sidebar to find out the handmade goodies you can receive for your level of donation.

Other Ways You Can Help

You know I’m all about DIY, but self-promotion is not my strongest skill. I’d be ever so grateful if you could help me help get to Rwanda by telling your friends and family about my campaign and the joyous girls of Ubushobozi.

Visit Ubushobozi.org to learn more about the project, meet the girls, and find how you too can become a volunteer.  Maybe you'll discover a way you can help you never knew was possible. I'll be sure to put you in touch with our volunteer coordinator.

Love and gratitude,
Leigh

story:
Who I Am & What I'm Doing

My name is Danielle Renae Kathryn Then and I am a 21-year-old college student from Guernsey Wyoming. As promised, here is the Google Maps link so you can see where I grew up:

https://maps.google.com/maps?q=Guernsey,+WY&amp...

 

It doesn't look like it, but I promise there is civilization. You just have to zoom in.

I was raised by a single parent and I have paid for college by myself up to this point. My father would give me the would if he could, but even the tuition in Wyoming was too much for him to assist me with. 

I recently moved to Los Angeles to attend USC, which, for me, is a dream come true. When I was in Wyoming I didn't have access to the resources I needed to become a psychologist. Now that I am here, everything I need is at my fingertips. This is, of course, at the cost of just under $30,000 a semester. Everything that I cannot cover with need-based and performance-based financial aid has been taken out in student loans, which are piling high at this point. 

This semester, I was accepted into the East Asian Studies Center's Global East Asia progam in Shanghai. The program is insanely competitive, and with good reason. The opportunity I have been afforded to study culture and social interaction is priceless. In this case it does have a pricetag, however. Including my plane ticket from Denver to LAX, I'll be spending a little over $6,000. There are no institutional student loans for me, as the class is only 4 credit hours, and the minimum requirement for summer financial aid is 6 credit hours. That's where you come in... 

 

What I Need

Roughly $500 to pay for my plane ticket from Denver to Los Angeles to begin the program in May. 

4 credit hours summer tuition, at $1,473 per unit, which comes to $5,892 total. 

That's it.

 

What You Get

1. My eternal gratitude. In this case, my gratitude will be expressed in the form of a postcard from China with an original poem.

2. Anyone who donates more than $20 gets a handmade keychain. A woman who is very important to me offered her help in this campaign and will be making panda-shaped keychains to raise funds. They will be infused with love, I assure you. 

3. For donations more than $200, I have decided to compensate you with something that is very important to me; a panda. I have been collecting them since I was young and each has its own name and uique story, which will be written up and shipped along with the panda. My only request is that you take care of them! Each one is a small piece of my life story. 

 

The Impact

I could spend five hours a day for the rest of my life reading about studies on cultural difference, and never really learn how to be an effective psychologist. Anyone in the mental health/medical field knows that experience is everything. By helping me go to China, you are helping me become the best I can be, so that I can help others as effectively as possible. 

You are helping me to never have to say the words "I don't understand" to any of my patients. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help monitarily, trust me, I understand (story of my life). If you want to, you can share my story! Or you could lend words of encouragement! Every little bit helps, trust me. My facebook is https://www.facebook.com/thdani?ref=tn_tnmn, feel free to add me!

story:
Olimpico Learning is a 501(c)(3) educational organization dedicated to affordable high quality customized education. We offer academic summer camp and enrichment programs. Our values are to engage students in a thriving and challenging summer camp environment that uses technology to improve skills in Math and English Language Arts. We are a, San Jose-based start-up dedicated to developing innovative summer camp and educational programs focused on building academic excellence.

Olimpico Learning partners with Robert F. Kennedy Elementary School in San Jose, CA. The summer program will consist of four weeks of both a morning academic program and afternoon learning exploratory camp. 
Weekly science-based themes are Astronomy, Biology, Chefology, Ecology. We focus on language arts, science, math and diverse academic electives. Students are engaged through hands-on learning, science exploration, art activities, group learning and technology-based projects as they follow the class theme throughout the weekly sessions.  

Our goal is to provide scholarships for 10 students to attend our 4-week STEM/STEAM academic program.

Scholarship Breakdown: 

  • Half-day scholarships @ $20 each
  • Full-day scholarships @ $40 each
  • One week scholarships totaling $200 per student

Olimpico Learning has learned from our collaboration and partnerships with experience teachers and leading educational organizations such as NASA, Adobe, Cisco, Google, Intel, and charter schools to build an enriching learning program with a special focus on socio-economically disadvantaged students to help them acquire greater in-depth knowledge of Math and English Language Arts.  Students at the schools we serve cannot afford high quality academic summer camps.  These students have a higher need for continuous learning opportunities in the summer. They struggle to make adequate progress during the school year and  they have trouble maintaining skills over the summer. 

We are excited about what we are doing and its potential to benefit our students.  At the same time, we anticipate that there may be risks and challenges that accompany this program. Our student population come from a low income Title 1 school which is 89% Hispanic and its students are predominately English Learners; 80% of our students are eligible for federal breakfast and lunch assistance. Many of the students' families have a challenging educational history. Our program will encourage and support these students to follow pathways to their futures that are fueled with continual learning, investigation of STEAM, cooperation and team building with others, and high expectations for themselves.

We understand that financial contributions are often difficult. There are other ways that you can help us:

  • Share our vision! Spread the word and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Act now and use the Indiegogo share tools to let your circles, your tribes, your friends and your families know about the learning opportunities with Olimpico Learning. 
  • Connect with Olimpico Learning via our website.
  • Utilize the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
¿Cómo pagar?

 

¿Otra forma de llevar Tullpi a casa? Escríbenos a hello@tullpi.com

Creamos Tullpi porque vemos a los niños frustrados con las formas convencionales de aprender matemática.

Tullpi transforma las matemáticas en un experimento constante, creando una conexión intuitiva entre lo abstracto de los números y objetos en el mundo real. Los niños usan simples tapas de botella para resolver desafíos matemáticos con sus propias manos.

Tullpi ofrece un kit que transforma tu iPad en una estación de aprendizaje y juego a la vez. Además por cada kit que compras, nosotros implementamos uno en un colegio público de una zona vulnerable.

Tullpi te ofrece 3 juegos y pronto muchos más:

Aprende matemáticas jugando con tapitas


Crea música jugando con tapitas


Aprende a escribir dibujando


Muchas gracias por tomar el tiempo para conocer más acerca de nuestra historia.

Si tienes alguna pregunta o sugerencia, no dudes en escribirme a adolfo@tullpi.com o llámarme al (+51) 973950936. 

Estamos para servirte :)

De los 4 a los 7 años, los niños se encuentran en la etapa pre-operacional, enfrentando lo que es probablemente el más grande reto de su desarrollo cognitivo: la transición de entender el mundo a través de sus sentidos (llamado pensamiento concreto) a representar la realidad mediante símbolos, conceptos y modelos (llamado pensamiento abstracto). A esta edad los niños requieren el uso de elementos tangibles para ser capaces de procesas información y constantemente probar sus ideas..

Es por eso que los mejor programas educativos alrededor del mundo se enfocan en el uso de elementos tangibles para ayudar a los niños a superar este desafío.

Nosotros lo llevamos a otro nivel.

Tullpi crea un puente entre el mundo que el niño naturalmente entiende y estos nuevos conceptos.



Con Tullpi, tu hijo aprende a contar, sumar, restar, qué son las unidades, decenas, centenas, cómo hallar el doble y la mitad, ¡Gana estrellas y conquista planetas! En resumen, todo lo que los niños tienen que aprender en el primer año del colegio, pero ¡de manera divertida!


En colegios donde no pueden permitirse el comprar el material convencional usado para aprender matemáticas (porque es costoso), les piden a los padres coleccionar tapitas de botella. Esta es una genial solución, las tapas de botella son fáciles de manipular y vienen en diferentes colores.

El reflector tiene dentro un pequeño espejo inclinado que se coloca encima de la cámara frontal de la Tablet (como se muestra abajo). De esta forma, la cámara capturará el área de la mesa que está justo en frente de la Tablet, detectando así la posición y color de las tapitas de botella.

En la imagen siguiente, puedes ver cuál es el rol que cumple el reflector y cómo funciona la detección de tapitas.

Somos de Perú y nuestro país ocupó el último lugar de educación matemática, tal como se muestra en el gráfico siguiente. Es por eso que sentimos que algo debía hacerse.

Pero lo triste acerca de estos resultados es que están fuertemente atados al nivel socioeconómico, lo que significa que hay una gran brecha entre la calidad de educación que unos cuantos recibe y la deficiencia o inexistente educación que el resto recibe. Este escenario está también presente en varios otros países, sobretodo en Latinoamérica.


Por cada kit comprado, nosotros implementamos otro en un colegio de un área rural o vulnerable.

Alrededor del mundo, existen diversas iniciativas, tales como Xprize Global Learning Challenge o Curious Learning, que buscan llevar tablets, con contenido educativo, que permitan a los niños de zonas vulnerables y rurales lograr los niveles básicos de literatura y aritmética. Gracias al precio decreciente de las tablets, creemos que es una oportunidad para crear un impacto real.

Nos hemos esforzado mucho en hacer que nuestros juegos funcionen de manera correcta incluso en tablets de bajo presupuesto y sin conexión a internet, con la intención de ser capaces de implementar Tullpi junto a programas enfocados en mejorar el aprendizaje de las matemáticas mediante el uso de tecnologías de información.

¿Qué es Maba?

Maba es una iniciativa educativa sin fines de lucro, que en asociación con Curious Learning (Global Literacy Project), busca mejorar los niveles de aprendizaje de matemáticas y ciencias en los colegios más vulnerables del país a través de la donación de tablets, la implementación de una conexión a internet veloz y el acceso irrestricto a un sin número de contenidos educativos digitales.

Ellos empezaron el año pasado con siete colegios, logrando resultados extraordinarios (un incremento de hasta 12% en competencias matemáticas). Estos resultados aceleraron su crecimiento, haciendo que este año se expanda a 14 colegios.

El reto

Tullpi será implementado en los primeros 7 colegios de Maba, para todos los niños de primer grado de primaria, ¡alrededor de 700 niños! Este es solo nuestro primer reto y para lograrlo ¡Necesitamos de su ayuda!

Aquí puedes ver donde se encuentra ubicados los colegios.



La base y el reflector están fabricados en triplay cortado en laser.

Este kit fue especialmente diseñado para la tablet que es utilizada en estas escuelas. Debido a que la cámara de la tablet se encuentra localizada a un lado (en lugar del centro) y su ángulo de apertura es muy angosto, la tablet tiene que ser colocada a una mayor altura e incluimos un tablero que ayuda al niño a colocar las tapas en el lugar correcto y tener una mejor idea de su area de juego.

Los kits donados van al colegio en cajas de 12 kits (twelve pack), esto es para facilitar el manejo de éstos a los profesores y optimizar espacio.


Por tu generosa colaboración podrás recibir geniales recompensas:
